clean_wm_text: Er Pulsae (Aurigae) is an F-type main-sequence star with a mass of 1.8 solar masses and a radius of 2 solar radii, located about 40 light-years away in the constellation Auriga.
For many years, it has been known for being surrounded by dust materials that obscure its visible spectrum.
The detected excess infrared radiation around the object indicates that it may have a stellar formation disk similar to those around T Tauri stars or Herbig Ae/Be stars.
In addition, there are signs that the system contains a close companion star, which may also contribute to the observed infrared excess emission.
We have provided new photometric observation data obtained using the UK Infrared Telescope (UKIRT) at Mauna Kea from 1997 to 2001, covering a wavelength range of 0.9 to 2.5 microns.
These data indicate that there are significant variations in the near-infrared flux and color of the central source, which is consistent with the changes in the amount of dust around the star.

This behavior is very similar to what has been observed in other pre-main-sequence systems, where the accretion of the central star leads to a periodic increase in brightness, while the heating of surrounding dust particles also results in an increase in reddening.

Our results indicate that the activity level in the current system is relatively低 compared to previous periods, but we cannot rule out the possibility that the recent increase in brightness is due to a transient enhanced accretion outburst, rather than a steady-state accretion that occurs continuously during our observation period.

We present new near-infrared (NIR) polarimetric observations of the GG Tau system, which reveal that its circumstellar disk is highly structured and contains multiple bright regions with different polarization characteristics.
The most significant feature in our dataset is an arc-like structure located approximately 0.5 arc seconds southeast of the central binary star.
The region displays strong polarized radiation, reaching 10% of the total intensity, previously identified as a reflection nebula by Weintraub et al. (1993).
We found that this feature can be explained by scattering from optically thin dust particles near the mid-plane.
Additionally, we discovered two other bright features on either side of the central binary stars.
These are also related to a high degree of linear polarization, but there is no evident evidence of the presence of scattered light.
On the contrary, they seem to be caused by the absorption of radiation from background stars.
Finally, we identified three additional darker structures in the southern part of the disk.
All these features have similar polarization angles, indicating that their origins may be related.
We reported the phenomenon of fluidizing a thin horizontal vibrating particle bed through low-frequency and small-amplitude vertical vibrations.
The system conducted experimental research using a combination of high-speed video imaging and particle tracking velocimetry (PTV).
We found that for sufficiently large vibration amplitudes, particles are ejected into the air from the surface when they move upward to reach their highest point.
This leads to the formation of a thin gas phase above the dense accumulation near the bottom of the container.
In addition, we observed convective rollers transporting particles throughout the depth of the bed layer.

These results show significant similarities to those observed in beds of vibrating sand or glass beads, but there are significant differences compared to previous studies that applied only horizontal vibrations in the system.
Vibration can induce transitions between different states of matter, such as solid, liquid, and gas. [1]
For example, it has been proven that when a solid state is subjected to periodic external forces, it may become unstable, thereby spontaneously generating propagating waves.
An especially interesting situation occurs when the horizontal and vertical components of the driving force act simultaneously [4].
In this work, we studied the response of thin particle layers subjected to simultaneous horizontal and vertical vibrations.
Our experiments reveal previously unseen phenomena that occur in other types of driven granular media.

We present new near-infrared photometric data from the Pleiades cluster obtained with the 1-meter telescope (Infrared Survey Facility, IRSF) at the South African Astronomical Observatory in November 2005.
The observation was conducted using the IRSF/SIRIUS camera, which has the capability to perform JHKs imaging simultaneously within an 8x8 field of view.
We also used the 2MASS data from the archives to supplement our sample.
Our results are presented in the form of color-magnitude diagrams (CMDs), showing that our luminosity measurements are in good agreement with previous studies.

Using these CMDs, we identified several previously unreported candidate members of the Seven Sisters star cluster based on their positions relative to the theoretical pre-main sequence evolutionary tracks.
These candidates include two objects located at the substellar boundary, one of which appears to be a brown dwarf in the Pleiades star cluster.

We reported radio observations conducted using the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA) at frequencies of 5 GHz and 8.6 GHz, which revealed an unresolved point source coinciding with G1, one of the heaviest globular clusters known to exist in our Milky Way galaxy.
The observed flux density is consistent with that expected from a black hole accreting at the Eddington limit.
We also presented new optical spectra obtained using the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph (GMOS), and the results showed no evidence of emission lines associated with gas around the central object.
These results are inconsistent with previous claims that the star cluster contains a supermassive black hole.
If future research confirms these findings, then they will represent the first discovery of intermediate-mass black holes in any galaxy.
This discovery is significant for understanding how such celestial bodies form and evolve over cosmic time.
In addition, it will provide insights into the formation history of the galaxy itself.

We introduce the concept of "abstract factorial," which refers to functions that can be used to effectively represent and manipulate sets of integers.
We demonstrate how to use standard data structures, such as hash tables or trees, to implement these functions.

Finally, we present several applications of this new category of objects, including a fast algorithm for calculating the number of integer partitions with a finite number of parts (the so-called "second kind Stirling numbers") and the number of ways to tile a rectangular board with tiles of different sizes.
The concept of abstract factorials is introduced, while being implemented on existing data structures such as hash tables or binary search trees.

1 Introduction: In many computing environments, it is necessary to perform operations on large sets of integers.

For example, it may be necessary to calculate the number of ways to partition a set into subsets of equal size, or to calculate the number of ways to tile a rectangular chessboard using tiles of different shapes and sizes.
These calculations usually require the repeated evaluation of arithmetic expressions involving sums and products of integers.
Recent research has shown that certain categories of such expressions can be represented very efficiently by combinatorial objects known as "factorials."

The factorial is essentially a function that maps each positive integer \( n \) to another object \( f(n) \), referred to as the "value" of the factorial at \( n \). Such values can satisfy two properties:

First, they should form a sequence of non-negative integers whose sum grows exponentially; that is, there exists some constant \( c > 0 \) such that for any factorial value, it satisfies \( |f(n)| \leq cn^c \) for all sufficiently large \( n \). Second, the values of different factorials should not collide too frequently; more precisely, if \( f(n_1) = f(n_2) \), then \( n_1 \) and \( n_2 \) must differ by at least a fixed amount \( d \).
Globular clusters are dense stellar systems containing thousands to millions of stars, and they are considered to be some of the oldest gravitationally bound objects known.
The discovery of planets around other stars has raised questions about whether members of globular clusters can also have planetary systems.
In this work, we use Monte Carlo simulations to investigate how many planets may exist in globular clusters of varying masses and ages.

We found that under most reasonable assumptions of planetary formation rates, every star should have at least one planet, except for some of the very young (<10 million years) and lowest mass (<100 solar masses) star clusters.
This result has strong robustness regarding our uncertainty about the efficiency of planet formation and initial conditions, such as the number density distribution of planetary embryos.
Our research results indicate that with current observational techniques, it will be possible to detect planets orbiting members of globular clusters.
Keywords: planetary systems; stellar evolution; star clusters; formation.
The work function is one of the most important parameters in semiconductor devices, and its accurate measurement is crucial for device design and performance prediction.

In this article, we review recent progress in determining the work functions of various materials using ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) in combination with other techniques such as scanning tunneling microscopy/spectroscopy (STM/STS), inverse photoemission spectroscopy (IPES), and kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM).
We also discussed how to determine the absolute value of the work function of different semiconductors based on UPS measurements.
Finally, we have presented our views on the future research directions in this field.

The work function is an important parameter in semiconductor devices, determining the electrical characteristics of the device, including carrier transport behavior and the height of the Schottky barrier.

We have directly measured the stellar radius in an interacting binary star system for the first time using interferometric observations obtained with the VLTI and AMBER instruments.

We have for the first time analyzed the composition of the tight binary star system SS Leporis (with an angular separation of about 0.3 arc seconds), which consists of two main-sequence stars, both of which are filling their respective Roche lobes.

By fitting the theoretical model to our data, we found that the size of one component is slightly larger than the theoretical expectation, while the radius of the other component is consistent with predictions based on evolutionary tracks.
This result indicates that during the process of these stars evolving toward contact, tidal interactions have altered their radii.

Our results also indicate that the orbital inclination i = 60 ± 5 degrees, a value that was previously determined through radial velocity measurements, is very consistent with our new estimate derived directly from the observed separation between the two stars.
Keywords: interferometry; binary stars; stellar radius.

We presented the results of an optical monitoring campaign focused on two bright quasars with redshifts of z = 1.7 and 2.1, aimed at investigating their long-term linear and continuous variability characteristics.
The observation was conducted between September 2005 and December 2007, using the Nordic Optical Telescope (NOT) equipped with ALFOSC.
We found that these two objects show significant changes on time scales ranging from a few months to several years.
In particular, we detected significant changes in the Hβ emission line profile, which were accompanied by fluctuations in the flux density of the corresponding continuous spectrum region.
These findings suggest that the observed spectral variations can be explained as a variable obscuration effect caused by the movement of clouds between us and the central engine.
This scenario is supported because the detected variations seem to occur simultaneously in all three Balmer lines studied here.
In addition, we found evidence of additional short-term volatility events occurring on certain nights.
We present new infrared (IR) photometric measurements of the galaxy cluster MS1054-03 obtained with ISOCAM using the ISO satellite at redshift z = 0.83.
These data are used to study the star formation activities in this rich stellar cluster environment.
We found that the infrared luminosity function can be well-fitted by a Schechter function, with L* ~ 1 x 10^12 L⊙ and α ~ -1.7, applicable in the range of 8-1000 microns.
This result indicates that there may be an excess of faint galaxies compared to local galaxy clusters.
In addition, we detected several bright sources, which have been identified as candidates for active galactic nuclei based on their mid-infrared colors.
These objects seem to preferentially reside near the center of the star cluster, suggesting that they may be triggered by interactions or mergers between galaxies.
Finally, we combine our results with the published optical spectra to study how the characteristics of individual galaxies evolve over time.
We propose an analytical model to describe the evolution of 21 cm brightness temperature fluctuations during the reionization of the universe, which is based on correlated random walks (CRWs).

We have demonstrated that the CRW model can reproduce many of the features observed in numerical simulations of reionization, including the large-scale power spectrum and the characteristic shapes of cross correlations between different redshifts.

In addition to these results, we found that our model predicts a new feature that has not been observed in previous studies—namely, the existence of large-scale correlations even after reionization is complete.
This effect may be detected in future radio telescopes, such as SKA.
The 21 cm line emission of neutral hydrogen provides us with a unique tool to probe the early universe.
It enables people to study the process of re-ionization, when most of the matter was still dark matter, with cold gas clouds surrounded by ionized bubbles.

These works indicate that there are two main types of features associated with reionization.

We present the results of an optical imaging survey of the nearby galaxy cluster centered on M31 using Subaru/Suprime-Cam, including its brightest satellite galaxy—Andromeda II (M32).
We have conducted a detailed study of the internal structure and stellar populations of Andromeda II using this data for the first time.
The surface brightness profile shows that Andromeda II can be well described by two exponential components, which are approximately 1 kiloparsec apart along the major axis.
The double exponential shape suggests that Andromeda II is composed of two different components, with one component being younger than the other.
Using the SSP model, we found that the ages of these two components are 2 billion years and 10 billion years, respectively.
In addition, several small knots are distributed throughout the entire Andromeda II galaxy, which may be related to recent star formation activity.
The positions of these nodes show no obvious correlation with the previously discovered globular clusters or HII regions.

We provide new luminosity measurements from the globular cluster NGC 1904, obtained using the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) on the Hubble Space Telescope, covering optical and near-infrared wavelengths through four filters.
We found that this star cluster has an extended blue horizontal branch (BHB), which includes both hot blue horizontal branch stars (BHBs) and blue stragglers (BSs).
In order to study these groups separately, we used two different methods.
First, we select based on the position of stars on the red giant branch (RGB); secondly, we use the color magnitude diagram (CMD) of the best-fitting model as input for artificial star tests.
The results obtained from these two methods are consistent.
Our analysis shows that the proportion of white dwarfs among all evolutionary stars is f = 0.11 ± 0.01.
The value is consistent with previous research findings on other star clusters.
Using theoretical models, we estimate the age of the star cluster to be t = 1.2 billion years.

The variation in the values of physical constants is one of the most important issues in modern physics, cosmology, and astrophysics.

The main goal of this work is to study the possible temporal variations of some fundamental constants (the fine-structure constant α, the gravitational constant G, and the proton-to-electron mass ratio μ) using different theoretical approaches and observational data from distant celestial objects.
In our previous research, we have shown that the redshift observed in quasars can be explained by a varying fine-structure constant over cosmic time.
We also found that the evolution of the universe may lead to changes in other fundamental constants, such as the gravitational constant or the mass ratio of protons to electrons.
Here, we present the new results obtained within these model frameworks.
First, we demonstrate how the model based on the varying fine structure constant explains the recent measurements of quasar absorption lines at high redshifts conducted by Webb et al. (1999).
Next, we discuss the possibility of using the same method to explain the recently measured Hubble parameter by Freedman et al. (2001) of H0 = 72 ± 8 km s⁻¹ Mpc⁻¹.
Finally, we consider another class of models where all three fundamental constants vary simultaneously.
We provide new constraints on warm dark matter (WDM) models by combining the results of two recent gravitational lensing quasar surveys, SDSS and CFHTLS Wide.

This result suggests that the current warm dark matter scenario might need to be revised, or that there are other systematic effects in our analysis that have not been accounted for.

We report high-precision radial velocity measurements conducted with the HARPS spectrograph, detecting an exoplanet orbiting the nearby (distance = 8.3 parsecs) M3V star GJ 674. This is part of our ongoing survey using this instrument to search for short-period low-mass companions.
The minimum mass of the new planet is Mp = 1.1 MJup, with a period P = 3.6 days.

This was discovered through the combination of two independent methods: the analysis of the bisector span of the cross-correlation function and the analysis of the full width at half maximum of these functions.

We present mid-infrared (MIR) spectra from the central region of the Virgo cluster, obtained with high spatial resolution using the Spitzer Space Telescope/IRS.

The MIR emission is primarily dominated by features characteristic of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and silicate absorption bands, which extend over a range of thousands of parsecs along the short axis direction of the galaxy.
We have found evidence of an additional component to this emission, which peaks 0.5 arcseconds (0.1 seconds of arc) above the nucleus.
This nuclear source was previously detected as a compact radio core and a near-infrared continuous source, but it has not yet been observed in the infrared spectral domain.
It shows strong polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) emission lines, accompanied by weak fine structure line emissions.
Through superposition, we detected multiple other sources in the field of view, including two bright starburst galaxies located about 10 arcminutes from M87.
The results indicate that even in crowded areas like the center of rich clusters such as Virgo, the infrared properties can still be studied.

We present new numerical results on the accretion disk structure in black hole (BH) binary systems, as well as their observational features, including the occultation effects caused by the black hole shadow and the reflective characteristics resulting from the strong gravitational lensing effect.

We consider two different types of models: one is geometrically thin but optically thick; the other has an extended atmosphere that could be optically thick or thin depending on the density distribution.
In both cases, we find that the observed flux strongly depends on the angle of inclination between the orbital plane and our line of sight.

For low inclination angles, the system appears very bright because most of the radiation comes from the disk facing us; however, at high inclination angles, only a small portion of the radiation reaches us, while most is obscured by the black hole itself.

The profile of the resulting eclipse is very sensitive to the spin parameter of the black hole \( a^* = \sqrt{M^2} \), which determines how much of the accretion disk is obscured during each orbital motion.
This effect may provide a method to measure the spin of supermassive black holes through observations of X-ray binaries.
We present a sample of BLOX clusters based on optical data obtained with Megacam at the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope (CFHT) and X-ray data obtained from Chandra or XMM-Newton.
We selected galaxy clusters in a 1 square degree area around the field center of the Advanced Camera for Surveys on the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) using photometric redshift.
Our selection is based on the significance of detecting high-density regions in the color space and their brightness function.

This resulted in a total of 1253 candidate galaxy clusters between z=0.3 and z=0.9.

We study the relationships between entanglement that can be extracted from two types of quantum systems (spin chains with nearest-neighbor interactions and harmonic oscillator lattices), the entropy-area law (EAL), and von Neumann entropy.
We state that the EAL (Energy Area Law) holds if and only if the ground state is unique or degenerate.

For non-degenerate ground states, we prove that there exists an infinite family of pure product states that can be arbitrarily close to the ground state, but cannot be obtained through local operations and classical communication (LOCC).

The Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) is an ideal laboratory for studying galaxy structure, stellar populations, chemical evolution, and cosmology, due to its many advantages compared to other nearby galaxies, such as the Andromeda Galaxy (M31) or the Triangulum Galaxy (M33).
The distance to the LMC can be determined using blue supergiants, which are bright periodic variable stars that pulsate in a radially fundamental mode.
In this study, we used two different methods to determine the distance to the Cepheid variables in the Large Magellanic Cloud.

The first method is based on a nonlinear least squares fitting technique called testimator, while the second method is based on a statistical analysis known as the Schwartz Information Criterion (SIC).
We found that these two methods produced consistent results within their ranges of uncertainty.
Our final sample includes 1,228 Cepheid variable stars located between 30 to 50 kiloparsecs from the center of the galaxy.
Using these datasets, we have derived a new period-luminosity relation for classical Cepheids in the infrared bands JHKs.

Abstract: We consider the gravitational interaction problem between these objects from the perspective of information content.

The main idea here is that a gravitational field can be viewed as a collection of gravitons/quantum particles that carry information about the source, while gravitational waves are seen as carriers of information regarding the motion state of gravitational objects.

This viewpoint allows us to provide explanations for certain phenomena observed in astrophysical environments (such as the Pioneer anomaly) as well as phenomena in a cosmological context (such as dark energy).
In addition, we recommend using the concept of "information potential" to describe the evolution of the universe.
We conducted a comprehensive visible light spectral study of all known Jupiter Trojans (JTs) for the first time.
We obtained high-resolution spectra from Subaru/HDS, Gemini/GNIRS, and Keck/NIRC-2 to determine their surface compositions.
The sample includes 49 JTs, among which there are two new findings from our team.
Our analysis shows that most JTs are S-type or C-type asteroids.
However, we have identified four objects with unusual spectral characteristics; among them, one is an E-type asteroid, while the other three exhibit featureless red sloped continuous spectra.
These objects may be primitive celestial bodies, such as carbonaceous chondrites.
In addition, we found that some JTs belong to the dynamic cold family.
This indicates that these families were recently formed through catastrophic collisions between their maternal lineages.
Finally, we discussed the possible scenarios for the formation of JT based on our findings.
Keywords: Asteroid

We present an analysis of the properties of giant planet candidates detected by the Optical Gravitational Lensing Experiment (OGLE), which has monitored stars in the center of the Milky Way for over a decade.
We found that most of these systems are likely composed of two low-quality bodies, each with a mass less than 0.5 times that of Jupiter, orbiting each other with periods exceeding 100 days.
Most of the orbital inclinations are close to 90 degrees.
These results suggest that many planetary-mass companions found around nearby sun-like stars may also exist around distant red giants.
This is important because it allows us to use high-resolution spectroscopy to study their climatic components.
Keywords: planetary systems; planets; transit exoplanet search; red giants; bulge; massive star formation; stellar evolution; exoplanets; astrophysics.
We present new HST/ACS observations of four nearby Fanaroff-Riley Type I (FR I) radio galaxies: 3C 31, 3C 264, 4C+55.17, and PKS 0745-191.
We used this data to study their nuclear characteristics through aperture photometry and image decomposition techniques.

The results show that all sources have an unresolved core component, with typical luminosities ranging between \(10^{40}\) to \(10^{50} \, \text{erg} \, \text{s}^{-1} \, \text{Hz}^{-1}\) at the rest-frame wavelength of 5100 Å, which is consistent with previous studies based on ground-based near-infrared spectroscopy.
In addition, we found that among the four subjects of our study, two showed evidence of extended emission around the nucleus.
This extended radiation had only been detected in another FR I galaxy, namely M 87.
Our analysis indicates that this extended radiation can be interpreted as scattered light from the central source.

Finally, our results indicate that the observed polarization fraction increases at shorter wavelengths, suggesting that dust extinction plays an important role in determining the intrinsic polarization characteristics of these systems.

We study the quantum Hall effect (QHE) in monolayer graphene and its interaction with magnetism by using an effective low-energy model that takes into account electron-electron interactions and defect effects.
We demonstrated how to derive this model from fundamental principles and discussed some of its main characteristics.
In particular, we found that at half-filling, it exhibits two distinct phases depending on the strength of the Coulomb interaction between the electrons.

For weak coupling, these states are separated by a phase transition driven by the spontaneous breaking of time-reversal symmetry; for strong coupling, they correspond to the conventional quantum Hall effect (QHE) states and a novel fractionalized topological insulator characterized by chiral edge states.

The latter has been shown to be equivalent to a spin-1/2 Heisenberg antiferromagnet on a honeycomb lattice, and thus can be described within the framework of the so-called SU(4) bosonic representation.

We study the statistical properties of highly compressible turbulence through direct numerical simulation (DNS), with a Mach number range between 10 and 100, while using isothermal and adiabatic equations of state to describe the gas.
We found that the scaling laws observed in incompressible flow are violated when the Mach number is sufficiently high to generate shock waves.
In particular, we demonstrate that the energy spectrum varies with wave number k, exhibiting an exponential decay rather than the power-law behavior of E(k) ~ k^-5/3 predicted by Kolmogorov theory.
The intermittent characteristics of the flow have also been studied through the analysis of probability density functions (PDFs).
The results indicate that as M increases, the tail of the PDF becomes thicker, which can be explained by the presence of shock waves.
Finally, we discuss how these results may influence our understanding of astrophysical phenomena such as supernova remnants or interstellar clouds.
We present new results on the light element abundances (lithium, beryllium, and boron) of two low-metallicity objects in the globular cluster M4.

The observed abundance patterns are compared with the predictions based on the standard Big Bang nucleosynthesis theory, as well as with predictions that assume these elements were produced during the quiescent burning phase of massive AGB stars.
We found that neither of these two scenarios can simultaneously reproduce all three measured elemental ratios when the metallicity is below [Fe/H] = -2.0 dex.
This indicates that other processes must be responsible for generating lithium, beryllium, and boron in the star cluster.
These findings provide important clues about the sources of light elements in environments with low metallicity, such as dwarf galaxies or primordial gas clouds.
Especially, they believe that the production mechanism may differ from previous ideas.
Finally, we discussed the possible implications of our results on the formation history of globular clusters.
We analyzed the special velocities in the local universe based on data obtained from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS).
We use a sample of galaxies with measured redshifts and distances to map the velocity field around us.
The flow of results is consistently influenced by the dominant motion, which corresponds to our position in the void located approximately 50 Mpc from the center.
The results confirmed the findings of previous studies that used different methods.
In addition, we found evidence of a dipole component in this flow pointing towards the center of the void in the direction of Virgo.
Our results indicate that the overall motion of matter in the nearby universe may be influenced by large-scale structures.
These results are of significant importance for research on cosmological models and the formation and evolution of galaxies.
They also provided new constraints on dark energy theories.

We present the discovery and characteristics of two "hot Jupiter" planets that orbit around member planets in a wide binary star system, namely HD 196885AB (orbital radius = 1.8 AU) and HD 208598AB (orbital radius = 3.6 AU).
The planet surrounding HD 196885A is an inflated gas giant with a mass of M sin i = 0.88 MJup and an orbital period of 4.3 days; it is located just 0.04 AU away from its host star.
We found no evidence indicating the presence of companion stars with a mass as low as 5 Jupiter masses within 10 AU of the two main stars.
The orbital eccentricity of both systems is consistent with zero.
These results indicate that hot Jupiters can survive close encounters with other stars during their formation or early evolution.
Introduction: Hot Jupiters are large gas planets that orbit around sun-like stars in short-period orbits.
They represent one of the most extreme environments in our solar system, but they could be ubiquitous around nearby sun-like stars.
In fact, recent surveys indicate that about 20% of solar-type stars have such planets.

However, these planets are thought to have formed several astronomical units away and then migrated inward through interactions with the protoplanetary disk and/or gravitational scattering by other bodies.

This raises questions about how these planets managed to avoid being ejected into interstellar space after experiencing intense dynamical interactions with other celestial bodies, while still retaining enough angular momentum to reach their current positions near their parent stars.

In this letter, we report the detection of two new "hot Jupiter" planets through high-precision radial velocity measurements. These measurements were conducted over a period of more than eight years using the High Accuracy Radial velocity Planet Searcher (HARPS), which is installed at the European Southern Observatory's 3.6-meter telescope located at La Silla Observatory in Chile.
Among these planets, one has a very small semi-major axis of only 0.04 astronomical units, making it one of the known exoplanets closest to its host star.

We report observations made using the Chandra High Energy Transmission Grating Spectrometer (HETGS), which show significant variations in the absorption lines of the spectrum of the black hole candidate Cygnus X-1, which is believed to have strong winds and jets.

The observed spectral line profiles are consistent with expectations, indicating that these highly ionized iron atoms are moving along the line of sight towards the central source at speeds of up to 0.2c.
We found no evidence that the ionization state or column density of these absorbers shows significant changes on a timescale as short as one hour.
These results provide us with new insights into the physical conditions near the accretion disk surrounding this supermassive black hole.
This work was supported by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) under contract NAS8-03060.

Keywords: Black hole; wind; outflow; accretion disk  
Introduction: In recent years, there has been growing interest in studying the properties of winds and outflows associated with active galactic nuclei (AGN).
These flows may play an important role in regulating the growth of supermassive black holes by affecting the surrounding gas and radiation fields.
They also represent potential feedback sources between active galactic nuclei and their host galaxies.
However, despite many theoretical predictions about how this wind will behave, the limitations of direct observations remain limited due to the difficulty of observing them directly.

A promising approach is to use high-resolution spectroscopy to study the absorption features generated when foreground materials are viewed through the line of sight towards a continuous source at the center.

Recent observations of several nearby Seyfert 1 galaxies have shown clear evidence of variable absorption lines, which originate from photoionized plasma flowing out from the nucleus at velocities in the range of approximately ~100-1000 km/s (e.g., Kaspi et al., 2002; Crenshaw & Kraemer, 2003; McKernan et al., 2007).
Here, we present another example of a phenomenon based on deep observations of the brightest member among this class of Galactic Black Hole Candidates (GBHC) — Cygnus X-1, using Chandra/HETG.
Cygnus X1 is only 2 thousand parsecs away from Earth.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether virtual ultrasound (US) puncture trajectories can improve the effectiveness of percutaneous renal puncture in patients with complex anatomy and in those where the renal pelvis is difficult to visualize under fluoroscopy.
A total of 50 consecutive patients underwent ultrasound-guided percutaneous nephrolithotripsy, using an intra-room C-arm system for real-time imaging guidance.
The surgery is performed under general anesthesia or sedation.

Using OsiriX MD software, two urologists outlined the contours of the kidneys and identified all visible renal pelvises.

After successfully performing the puncture, attempt to retrieve the stone through the sheath inserted via the needle.

The overall success rate is 88%.
The use of the American puncture pathway projection did not result in any related complications.
This technology may assist urologists in achieving safe and efficient percutaneous renal puncture, even when only a few renal calyces are clearly visible under fluoroscopy.

We propose an efficient numerical scheme to solve the nonlinear dynamics of semiconductor microcavity lasers with arbitrary pump profiles and cavity losses, based on a combination of two different truncation schemes.

The first method is used to reduce the number of equations by eliminating any equations that are irrelevant at a given moment in time; this allows us to obtain accurate results even when only a few modes contribute significantly to the total emission spectrum.
The second method is applied to eliminate the rapid oscillation terms that arise due to the presence of multiple longitudinal modes in each transverse mode family.
We demonstrate how these two technologies combine into a single algorithm, which we call "Dynamic Control Truncation" (DCT).
Finally, we demonstrate the accuracy and efficiency of our method by comparing it with other existing methods.
Specifically, we consider three different types of pumping characteristics: constant pumping, periodic pumping, and stochastic pulse pumping.

The Long Baseline Neutrino Experiment (LBNE) is an international collaboration project aimed at constructing and operating a new accelerator-based neutrino beam facility in the United States, proposed to be located near Fermilab in Chicago, Illinois.
LBNE will adopt a novel proton driver design that combines two existing technologies—the cyclotron and the circular linear accelerator—into a compact system.
This report describes the status of the project as of September 2009.
It also presents some preliminary results regarding the physics potential of the LBNE project.

The Long-Baseline Neutrino Experiment (LBNE) is currently being developed under an international collaboration, with plans to build a new accelerator-based neutrino beam facility in northern New Mexico.

The facility will be located approximately 1,000 kilometers from the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (FermiLab) in Chicago, Illinois, and will be able to utilize the powerful NuMI neutrino beam generated there.

In addition to providing a high-intensity neutrino beam covering a wide energy range, the facility will also include a large liquid argon time projection chamber detector capable of measuring charged current interactions and neutral current elastic scattering events.
The facility will provide a unique opportunity to explore fundamental questions related to neutrino mass and mixing, CP violation, and other phenomena associated with neutrino oscillations.

Circinus X-1 is an X-ray binary system consisting of a neutron star and its companion star, which has been observed across multiple wavelengths from radio waves to gamma rays.

The MiniBooNE experiment recently reported an excess of electron neutrino-like events observed at low energy, which can be explained by a sterile neutrino with a mass of about 1 eV and a mixing angle of sin²(2θ) ~ 0.1.

In this work, we investigate how to incorporate these results into the framework of three-flavor lepton mixing, using the latest global data to fit experimental data on neutrino oscillation parameters and cosmological constraints on the sum of active neutrino masses.

We found that if we assume the observed excess corresponds to true neutrino oscillation into a phantom state, rather than being due to background systematics or statistical fluctuations, then the allowed parameter space is severely constrained.

The optimal values for the mass splitting of the sterile neutrino are Δm32 = (0.5 - 2.3) meV and Δm2 = (0.4 - 3.6) meV, while the corresponding range for the mixing angles is θ23 = 42° - 50° and θ13 ≥ 40°.

We proposed an analytical model of potentials that can produce multiple images in strong gravitational lensing, and we used these models to study how different mass distributions are constrained by observations.

We found that using just three or four multi-imaging systems with accurate spectral redshifts can effectively obtain a good constraint on the total enclosed mass within the Einstein radius (the projected distance of the two images combined) as well as the slope of the density distribution outside that radius.
The results presented here will help plan future surveys to measure the properties of dark matter through gravitational lensing effects.
The gravitational lensing effect provides one of the most powerful tools for studying the distribution of dark matter in galaxies and galaxy clusters.

Specifically, if a galaxy cluster forms several distinct images due to gravitational lensing, the positions and brightness of these images will provide information about the shape of the gravitational potential of the cluster, depending on the location along the line of sight.
This allows us to measure the total enclosed mass within a certain characteristic scale length, such as the Einstein radius, where the two images merge together.
However, due to the existence of many degeneracies among the parameters that describe the lens model, it is not always straightforward to determine which mass distribution best describes the data.

Issai Schur (1886-1967) was one of the most influential mathematicians of the twentieth century. His work had a significant impact on many fields, including number theory, functional analysis, operator theory, harmonic analysis, group representation theory, ergodic theory, probability theory, mathematical physics, computer science, statistics, numerical analysis, combinatorial mathematics, algebraic geometry, and dynamical systems.
In this lecture, we can review some of its contributions and emphasize their historical context.
We will also discuss how Schur's ideas have been developed by other mathematicians over the past seventy years.
This lecture aims to provide graduate students who are interested in understanding the history of modern mathematics and its latest developments.
This will be open to undergraduate students with a background in calculus with real variables and linear algebra.

We present the results of the cosmic ray data analysis collected by the PAMELA experiment in 2008 and 2009, showing an excess in the background within the energy range of 1-10 GeV/nucleon, which is consistent with particles accelerated in nearby supernova remnants (SNRs).

In this paper, we studied distributed algorithms for spectrum allocation, power control, routing, and congestion control problems in wireless networks.

We first consider the problem of Joint Channel Allocation and Power Control (JCAPC), which aims to minimize the total transmission power consumption while satisfying the quality of service constraints for each link.
The JCAPC problem is formulated as an integer programming problem and can be solved using standard linear programming techniques.
However, this centralized solution is impractical due to its high computational complexity.
To overcome these difficulties, we have proposed two distributed algorithms based on the dual decomposition method.
Our simulation results indicate that the algorithm we proposed requires only local information exchange between neighboring nodes to approach optimal performance.
Next, we will study the problem of Joint Routing and Congestion Control (JRCC).
This problem arises when there are multiple paths between the source and destination in the network.
The available bandwidth of each path varies due to its physical characteristics.

In order to achieve fairness among all flows sharing the public link, JRCC requires that the rate allocated to any flow should depend on both the current load of the path it uses and the number of competing flows.
We formulate the JRCC problem as a convex optimization problem, where the objective function is to maximize the overall utility of all users under certain capacity constraints at each node.
Then, we developed a distributed algorithm based on the original decomposition method to solve the JRCC problem.
Finally, we provide some numerical examples to demonstrate the performance of the algorithm we proposed.

This study emphasizes the importance of combining accurate photometric measurements over large areas with high-resolution spectroscopy in order to fully understand the characteristics of young open clusters like the Pleiades.

The proposed method is based on the concept of data partitioning, which allows us to allocate workloads to different nodes, thereby minimizing the communication costs between them.
We have demonstrated that our method can be a component of more complex queries, such as joins or aggregations.
Finally, we present experimental results demonstrating that our solution outperforms existing methods by several orders of magnitude when handling large datasets.
Relational Database Management Systems (RDBMS) are widely used because they can efficiently store and manage large amounts of information.
However, this efficiency comes at the cost of high computational complexity, as all data must be stored in the main memory during the processing.
If you want to perform temporary analysis on a large amount of data stored in a relational database management system (RDBMS), then this problem becomes even worse.
In fact, answering simple questions like "Which customers purchased product X?" or "Which products were sold together last year?" can take several hours or days.

In order to overcome these limitations, several recent research efforts have aimed to develop new technologies that allow users to access and analyze large amounts of data without needing to load all of the data into main memory at once.
These solutions often rely on parallel computing frameworks, where each node stores only a portion of the entire dataset and performs local computations independently of other nodes.
The background radiation in space is primarily dominated by cosmic rays and their secondary products, such as neutrons and gamma rays.
The most important source of these particles is supernovae in the Milky Way, with an average occurrence rate of one per century.

In this work, we present the results of background radiation measurements using the pn-CCD (p-type silicon charge-coupled device) that are expected to be used in the CERN Axion Solar Telescope (CAST).
We used GEANT4 Monte Carlo simulation to simulate the response of the CAST detector.
These models were then combined with the particle flux model in space to predict the background count rate observed by the camera.
Our predictions indicate that the background count rate resulting from cosmic ray interactions should not exceed 0.1 counts per pixel per second across the entire field of view of each camera.
This corresponds to less than 1% of the expected signal of axions generated in the solar magnetic field.
We presented the results of the volume operator in loop quantum gravity (LQG).
The volume operator is an important component in many physical applications, such as black hole entropy and cosmic disturbances.
We demonstrate that it can be represented as a sum over spin network states, with coefficients determined by the geometric structure of the underlying graph.
In particular, we found that the spectrum of this operator is completely consistent with the spectrum obtained using methods from group field theory.
This further demonstrates the equivalence between LQG and group field theory at the operator level.
Finally, we discuss how to use these results to calculate the expectation value of the volume operator in the semiclassical state.
These results will appear elsewhere.

The hot intergalactic medium (IGM) is an essential component in our understanding of galaxy formation, as it provides the fuel for star formation.
IGM is mainly composed of ionized hydrogen gas, with a temperature ranging from 10^6 K to 10^7 K, and a density range from 1 atom/cm^3 to 100 atoms/cm^3.
In this lecture, we will discuss how to utilize observations of the Lyman α forest to probe the physical properties of the intergalactic medium on large scales.

We will also present the results obtained from recent work, which are based on data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, indicating evidence of large-scale fluctuations in the temperature-density relationship of the intergalactic medium (IGM).
Finally, we will describe some current efforts aimed at measuring the thermal history of the universe by measuring the kinetic Sunyaev-Zel'dovich effect produced by galaxy clusters.
This research was funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) under grant number NAG5-13286.

In this discussion, we will explore the observation and detection of its physical properties on a large scale.

We present the results of subjective evaluation experiments conducted on forms intended for use in immersive environments, such as virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR).
The objective is to investigate how users perceive different form designs when immersed in these environments.

We compared three designs: the traditional two-dimensional form, the three-dimensional form rendered using perspective projection, and the three-dimensional form rendered using orthographic projection.
Our research results indicate that there is no significant difference between the two types of 3D morphologies.
However, the ratings for the two 3D forms were significantly higher than those for their 2D counterparts.
This indicates that 3D forms can be effectively used in immersive environments without the need for special rendering techniques or additional hardware.
In addition, we found that participants preferred forms that provided more visual cues to indicate depth information, rather than those without any such cues.
Finally, our research also indicates that it may be possible to create effective forms by combining elements from multiple existing designs.
We propose a video shooting image stabilization method based on super-resolution technology, suitable for turbulent environments.
The proposed method can be used to improve the video quality captured by handheld cameras or other devices affected by motion blur caused by turbulence.
We first estimate the camera motion through optical flow between consecutive frames.
Then we will use this information as input data for our super-resolution algorithm to generate high-resolution images.
Finally, these images are combined to produce a stable output frame.
Our experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods both visually and quantitatively.
Keywords: real-time video processing; turbulence; motion blur; optical flow; super-resolution; image stabilization.

We used two different methods to measure the speed of the galaxy clusters: one is based on spectral observations from member galaxies, and the other utilizes the luminosity redshift estimates of all galaxies within a fixed aperture, centered on the brightest group galaxy (BGG) of each cluster.

We present observations of 2MASS J04414489+2512172 from the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) and the Spitzer Space Telescope. This object is a young brown dwarf with a spectral type of M8, located in the upper Scorpius at a distance of 145 parsecs, surrounded by an edge-on circumstellar ring.
HST data shows that the celestial body is surrounded by a bright ring-like structure, extending to about 0.5′′ (approximately 120 AU).
We found evidence that the two spiral arms extend from the inside of the ring toward the center.
These features can also be observed in the near-infrared images obtained using the adaptive optics system NACO on VLT/UT4.
In addition, we found several nodes in these spirals, which may be caused by embedded dust clumps or asteroids.
Our results indicate that the observed structure may be formed due to gravitational instability caused by rapid inward migration of solids driven by gas drag.

We have conducted extensive research on the modal stability characteristics of the pulsating star δ Scuti (δ Sct), based on theoretical and observational results obtained from open star clusters ranging in age from 1 million to 2 billion years.
We performed detailed non-radial stellar oscillation calculations using the most advanced evolutionary models, which include superadiabatic convection boundaries and microscopic diffusion processes.
The main objective is to study how the observed frequency patterns change during evolution due to the effects of mixing and chemical composition gradients caused by rotation.
We pay special attention to the so-called hybrid modes, which are trapped in the region where the hydrogen burning shell overlaps with the helium core.
These patterns exhibit very typical characteristics, such as large amplitudes and high degrees of nonlinearity.
Our results indicate that these patterns can be excited by turbulent pressure fluctuations associated with convection zones located near the surface of celestial bodies.
In addition, they suggested that when stars evolve from the main sequence stage to higher luminosities, the excitation mechanism may undergo significant changes.
We report the discovery of two low-luminosity quasars (LLQs) with a redshift of about 4 in the quasar catalog from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 7.
LLQs are special in the spectrum; compared to typical quasars with similar redshifts, their emission lines are very weak.
We found that their optical-infrared spectral energy distribution can be well fitted by an accretion disk model with a very high black hole mass (M BH > 10^10 M☉) and Eddington ratio (L/L edd > 0.1).
These results suggest that these celestial bodies may represent a new class of supermassive black holes that grew rapidly through gas-rich mergers or interactions in the early universe.
Keywords: black hole mass, accretion disk modeling, supermassive black hole, quasar, redshift 4, optical-infrared spectral energy distribution.

We introduced an overview of our latest work on the production of vector mesons in heavy ion collisions, based on the holographic quantum chromodynamics model (AdS/QCD) with chiral symmetry breaking, at the energy levels of RHIC and LHC.

The detection of exoplanets is one of the most exciting developments in astronomy recently, but the characterization of these planets is still incomplete.
The goal of this paper is to develop new techniques to characterize exoplanet systems using dynamical methods.

In particular, I studied how planets can serve as a tool for probing the formation history of planetary systems by measuring the mass distribution of small celestial bodies (planetary embryos) that are in mean motion resonance with them.
My first project studied the effect of asteroid size on the orbital stability of planets.
Through numerical simulation, we found that smaller planetary embryos often make planetary orbits unstable more quickly than larger planetary embryos, as they have higher orbital eccentricities.
This result suggests that there may be an upper limit to the size of planetesimals formed during the process of planetary migration.
My second project studied the impact of mutual inclinations between planets on the stability of planetary systems.
We indicate that when two planets are in a 2:1 resonance, mutual inclination increases the likelihood of instability.
Finally, my third project explores the possibility of detecting Earth-like planets around white dwarfs through gravitational microlensing events.
We propose an optimal design method to find the best occlusion mask that can be used in direct imaging searches for exoplanets.
The proposed method is based on the concept of entropy maximization, which has been widely applied in various fields such as information theory and statistical mechanics.
We demonstrate how this concept extends to the optical field by introducing a new quantity called optical entropy (OE).
By using optical imaging, we are able to quantify the amount of information contained in the point spread function produced by each mask.
This enables us to determine the most effective mask shape for detecting faint companions around bright stars.
To demonstrate our approach, we conducted numerical simulations to compare the performance of several candidate masks.
Our results indicate that the proposed method offers a significant improvement over existing methods in finding the optimal mask shape for faint companions around bright host stars.

We presented a radiative transfer model for the dust distribution in the edge-on spiral galaxies NGC 891 and NGC 4565.
The model parameters are constrained by fitting the near-infrared (NIR) observation data at 2.2 microns from the NICMOS on the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) and the optical data obtained using WFPC-2.
We found that both galaxies have a large distribution of dust at significant distances along their disks.
In addition, we have detected an extended halo component around each galaxy, which is best described as a shell-like structure.
In NGC 891, the scale height of this component is 1 kiloparsec, extending upward above the disk by 5 kiloparsecs.
It contains about 10% of all dust mass within a distance of 10 kpc from the center.
In NGC 4565, our results indicate that the dust density exhibits an exponential decrease at greater heights, revealing a more complex geometric structure.
This work was funded by NASA under grant number NAG5-7085.
The mechanical properties of hair are determined by its molecular structure, which is mainly composed of a protein called keratin.
The main structural unit of keratin is the helical coil of α-helix, which forms microfilaments with other similar units, thus creating intermediate filaments (IFs).
These IFs then aggregate into bundles, forming microfibrils, which further gather together to create the basic building blocks of hair—cortical cells.
In this study, we explored how the mechanical properties change as these structures evolve during the process known as maturation or aging.
We used confocal Raman spectroscopy to measure the changes in secondary structure of individual keratin fibers extracted from human scalp hair at different stages of the growth cycle.
Our results show that the elastic modulus significantly increases when the fibers undergo a transition from the α-helix conformation to the β-sheet conformation.
This increase can be explained by the formation of hydrogen bonds between adjacent chains in the protein backbone.
In addition, our measurement results show that the presence of water molecules has a significant impact on the mechanical behavior of the fibers.
We present the results of N-body simulations aimed at studying tidal disruption and accretion in interacting galaxy pairs, with a particular emphasis on the formation of tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs).

We found that the formation of tidal debris galaxies (TDGs) has a strong dependence on the orbital parameters of interactions; specifically, we demonstrate that TDGs only form when the impact parameters of the collisions are less than about twice the sum of their effective radii.

In addition to the dependence on orbital geometry, our model indicates that if the ancestor galaxies have a higher gas fraction and/or lower central surface brightness, tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs) are more likely to form.
Finally, we believe that time-delayed gravitational waves (TDGs) could provide a useful probe for testing gravitational theories on galactic scales.

In the past decade or so, numerous instances of "tidal dwarf galaxies" (TDGs) have been discovered, prompting many authors to propose that these objects may be locations where star formation occurs during interactions between massive spiral galaxies.
However, despite extensive observational efforts, there is still no consensus on the frequency of TDG formation and whether these systems genuinely exist beyond the range of numerical simulations.
The purpose of this study is to examine the role of assessment in the communication between teachers and students in a computer-based learning environment (CBLE).
The guiding research question for this study is: How does it affect teacher-student interaction?
This study was conducted with two groups of undergraduate students enrolled in an introductory educational technology course at a large university in the Midwest.
Students are required to use a computer-based learning environment (CBLE) called WebQuests to complete three tasks. This environment is designed for students to use individually or collaboratively.

Data collection includes audio recordings of group discussions, field notes made by researchers during their observations of each group's work, and students' written responses to the questions posed during their participation in the project.

The analysis indicates that assessment plays multiple roles in these interactions, including providing feedback on individual performance; clarifying expectations; establishing fundamental rules; and facilitating reflection.

These findings indicate that when assessments are conducted frequently, they can effectively enhance communication between students and teachers, allowing both parties multiple opportunities to respond to each other.
We report the observation of measurement-induced decoherence phenomena in a Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC) using a Ramsey interferometer and atomic counting.

The experiment involves splitting a single captured Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC) into two spatially separated clouds, allowing them to evolve for different periods of time, and finally recombining them at a beamsplitter.
We observed that when we increase the number of atoms counted at one output port of the beam splitter, the visibility of the interference fringes decreases.
This effect can be explained by considering how repeated measurements influence the phase evolution of the system.
Our results indicate that cold atom experiments can be used to study fundamental issues in quantum mechanics.
Quantum mechanics predicts that any attempt to measure a physical quantity will disturb its value.
From this work, we experimentally investigate these effects in Bose-Einstein condensates (BEC).
To accomplish this, we conducted Ramsey interference experiments in two spatially isolated regions of the sample.
By changing the time spent on free evolution after separating out a portion of the initial cloud, we controlled the relative phase accumulated during the free evolution process.
After the reorganization, we counted the number of atoms arriving at each output port of the beam splitter and recorded their arrival time distribution.
As expected, we found that when the number of detected particles increases, the visibility of the resulting interference pattern decreases.
We present the results of the time-averaged spectrum and light curve analysis of GRB 090902B, which is one of the brightest bursts detected by Fermi/GBM (Gamma-ray Burst Monitor).
We found that its average spectrum can be well fitted using two blackbody functions plus an additional power-law component in the high-energy range.
The temperature of each black body decreases as the emission radius increases.
This behavior is consistent with the theoretical predictions of the radiation from the photosphere of relativistic jets.
In addition to this thermal component, we also detected non-thermal radiation above 100 MeV.

Our spectral fitting indicates that there are three different physical regions contributing to the observed gamma rays: 1) a photosphere-like region producing thermal radiation; 2) an internal shock region generating non-thermal radiation; 3) a magnetized wind region responsible for high-energy photons.
These findings provide new insights into the physics of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs).
Keywords: black body, photon index, power law

We consider the research problem of node line statistics in a random wave field. Here, we assume that the wave field is generated by a group of monochromatic waves with randomly distributed phases and amplitudes.
We demonstrated how to calculate these statistics using only the first two moments of the phase difference distribution function between the waves.
The results were applied to study the statistical properties of the internal tidal surface nodal lines in the ocean.

Specifically, research shows that the probability density function (PDF) of the number of intersection points per unit length of the reference curve strongly depends on whether the curve is located within one wavelength of the source region.
If this is the case, then within the high value interval of the intersection density, the probability density function has a power-law tail; if not, then there is no such tail.
Keywords: Random wave field, internal tides in the ocean, nodal lines, phase difference.
We propose new theoretical evolution tracks for stellar masses ranging from 1.8 to 2.5 M⊙, based on an improved treatment of convection in stellar interiors.

We use these tracks as input for our earthquake modeling code CESAM2k to compute the synthetic seismic waveforms corresponding to two sets of observed frequencies (from COROT) for two possible inclination angles, i = 90° or 60°.
The comparison between observation and theory shows that we can exclude one set of frequencies with high confidence, but we cannot exclude another set.
This is because the frequency difference between the ℓ=0 and ℓ=2 modes strongly depends on the tilt angle.
In addition, we found that the radius of the best-fit model is R=1.95R⊙, which is very consistent with the value derived from asteroseismology using only the ℓ=0 mode.
Finally, we demonstrate how to use this result to determine the age of stars.
Keywords: Earthquake Modeling

We report the detection of transient X-ray emissions in normal galactic nuclei (NGNs) using the Chandra and XMM-Newton telescopes, which may be associated with the accretion of supermassive black holes located at their centers.
The observed luminosity is consistent with the luminosity expected from stable nuclear activity driven by the mass flow through an optically thick disk surrounding the central black hole.
We found that the duration of the activity ranges from 10^3 to 10^5 years, depending on the distance between the NGN and the Earth.
This indicates that most newly formed galaxies may have undergone such a phase of activity during their life cycle.
Our results also suggest that the current quiescent state of most newly discovered quasars may be due to low levels of accretion or obscuration effects.
These findings provide new insights into the formation and evolution of massive galaxies and active galactic nuclei (AGN).
Keywords: Black hole accretion disk - Galaxy evolution - Nuclear activity
We studied the Witten function and vacuum density of Z_2 symmetric thick branes embedded in anti-de Sitter (AdS) spacetime with an extra dimension.
We found that, for the corresponding equations, there are two types of solutions depending on whether the mass is zero or not.

We proposed an algorithm that uses a weighted essentially non-oscillatory (WENO) scheme to numerically solve the time-dependent equations describing the growth of ionized regions in the early universe.

The numerical solution is obtained by simultaneously solving two coupled partial differential equations, which describe the evolution of the ionization fraction and temperature field within each cell of the grid covering the computation area.

We study evolutionary games conducted by agents randomly distributed on nodes in an unstructured network, where these agents only interact with their direct neighbors in the network.
We demonstrated how to solve the Nash equilibrium of such games through local computations at each node.
Our method is based on locally computing the best response within the neighborhood of each agent and then passing these responses as input to a global algorithm that calculates all Nash equilibria.

The main technical challenge lies in proving that our local algorithm can terminate after multiple rounds (depending on the number of participants), even if they may be executed concurrently in different parts of the network.

In particular, it applies to any undirected connected graph in which the degree of the vertices has a certain constant upper limit.

The universal spectrum is one of the most important concepts in physics and mathematics, widely used to study various physical phenomena, such as the energy transfer processes in biological systems.

We found that the coding region and the non-coding region correspond to two different types of universal spectra.
The universal spectrum of the encoding area shows power law behavior with an exponent of 1.5, while the non-encoding area exhibits fractal structure.
Our results indicate that the universal spectrum can be used to characterize the complexity of DNA sequences.
It will also provide new insights into understanding the evolution of genomes.

This study aims to explore some new effects observed in the combustion process of liquid fuels under the influence of laser radiation at different wavelengths and power densities.

We study the efficiency of a token system that allows users to purchase goods with their own currency or by exchanging it for others' currencies (tokens).
We indicate that when many buyers and sellers use this system for item transactions, if the majority have the incentive to become fair traders, then the system is efficient.
However, we also found that this situation does not always occur, as some users may attempt to hoard money, while others may exhibit altruistic behavior.
Specifically, we consider two types of user behavior: selfish and altruistic.
Selfish users maximize their utility in each transaction; they should only accept offers that provide them with more than what they pay.
Altruists do not care about maximizing individual utility, but rather hope to ensure that everyone can receive as much reward as possible.
We use game theory models to analyze these behaviors and derive the conditions for fair behavior among selfish and altruistic users.

We used the Density Matrix Renormalization Group (DMRG) method to study the temperature-driven phase transitions between different charge ordered states in the one-dimensional quarter-filled Hubbard model, which has nearest-neighbor hopping and onsite Coulomb repulsion.
We found that at low temperatures, the system is in a Wigner crystal state, and the electrons are localized due to strong electron correlations.

As the temperature rises, we observe that the first-order phase transition enters the state of bond charge density wave, a state that has been theoretically predicted before but has not yet been observed experimentally.
The nature of this phase transition can be understood as the melting of the Wigner crystal caused by thermal fluctuations.
Finally, we also studied the effect of the next nearest neighbor transition \( t' \) on these phases.
Our results indicate that for small values of t′, the ground state remains in the Wigner crystal phase, while for large values of t′, it transitions to the metallic phase.
This indicates that transitions beyond the nearest neighbors may disrupt the charge ordering in one-dimensional systems.
The Large Area Telescope (LAT) on the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope is scheduled to launch in June 2008 and will conduct at least three years of high-energy gamma-ray astronomy research.
The LAT consists of four identical towers, each equipped with a tracker and an energy measurement subsystem.
Each tower has a anti-coincidence detector that covers its entire surface area.

GBM consists of 12 sodium iodide scintillation crystals, which are read out using photomultiplier tubes.

The purpose of this article is to outline some of the latest results regarding quantum field theory (QFT) in curved spaces with non-commuting coordinates.

The main motivation for studying quantum field theories (QFTs) in such spaces comes from string theory, which is formulated using open strings attached to D-branes, where the positions of the D-branes can be described by non-commutative matrices.

We will pay special attention to the so-called Groenewald-Moyal plane, which is defined as a space generated by two non-commuting coordinates that satisfy the commutation relation [qμ(x), qν(y)] = iθμνρqρ(xy).
We will present a covariant derivative operator that can define a field acting on the Groenewold-Moyal plane.

We report an extremely bright galaxy with a strong gravitational lensing effect and spectral confirmation, which has a redshift of z = 3.1 (AB magnitude = 18.6). This galaxy was discovered while searching for high-redshift galaxies behind Abell 1689 using the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS).
Lens clustering is known to exist with a large number of arc-shaped objects, which are produced by multiple images from background sources.
We found that this object has six different components, which have similar colors and brightness, and are arranged along a line of sight distance of about 2 arc minutes.
This system appears to be a multiple imaging version, with intrinsic brightness comparable to that of the currently known brightest quasars.

The total flux density of all six components corresponds to a UV continuum luminosity of 1.5 x 10^26 W Hz^-1 in a stationary reference frame, which is about 100 times the brightness of any other known gravitational lensing galaxy.

We proposed an improved version of the nuclear matter properties and single-particle energies in spherical nuclei based on a covariant density functional theory that includes tensor terms, in order to enhance our previous calculations.
The new result is obtained by using a recently developed method to calculate the exchange-correlation contribution in the energy density functional, which does not contain any adjustable parameters.
We found that the calculated binding energy of each particle matches well with the results observed in experiments, except for certain light nuclei, such as 4He and 8Be.

We used a submillimeter wave array (SMA) to conduct new observations of outflows driven by massive protostars at 1.3 millimeters, and compared the results with those obtained previously using single-dish telescopes.

The dynamic-based method is an emerging approach to studying Earth-like exoplanets, which have masses similar to that of Earth and orbit other stars in the solar system.
The main objective of this study is to investigate how these planets form and evolve over time.

This method uses numerical simulation to model the formation and evolution of planetary systems by solving the equations that describe the orbital motion of celestial bodies under mutual gravitational interactions.
In addition, it also takes into account physical processes such as tidal dissipation, collisions between small celestial bodies (small rocky objects), and atmospheric escape.
