We present our analysis results of the supersymmetry parameter space, taking into account all available experimental data, including data from the LHC experiments and electroweak precision observations (EWPO).
We found that there is no significant improvement compared to previous analyses when we appropriately take into account the complete correlation of EWPOs.
However, if we only consider subsets of EWPOs that are not strongly correlated with each other, some improvements can be observed in certain regions of the parameter space.
This situation is especially applicable when the light neutral particle has a large Higgs weight component or when the glueball mass is around 1 TeV.
The latter also improved the consistency between theoretical predictions and the measured anomalous magnetic moment of the muon.
Finally, we discuss how these findings impact the prospects of discovering supersymmetry at future colliders, such as the International Linear Collider.

We studied the nonstationarity and synchronization characteristics of a group of coupled oscillators, where the coupling strength varies over time. The model utilizes phase equations similar to the Kuramoto model established on directed networks.
We proved that there is a critical value in the average degree, and when this value is exceeded, all nodes will synchronize with each other if they have the same natural frequency.
However, we find that even if the system is synchronized at some initial moment, it may become unsynchronized after a finite amount of time due to changes in the underlying topology.
Specifically, we demonstrate through analysis that this phenomenon occurs only in systems where the distribution of coupling strength has infinite variance.
Finally, numerical simulations confirmed our theoretical results.
This work was supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF) under grant number DMS-0805040.
The Cosmic Code Comparison Project is an effort aimed at comparing the results produced by different cosmological codes in order to test their accuracy.
The goal is to generate a set of simulated data that can serve as input for multiple codes, allowing each code to run on the same dataset.

This will allow us to determine the degree of agreement between these codes in terms of the physical quantities they predict (e.g., matter density distribution) and the statistical properties of these predictions (e.g., power spectrum).

We are currently working hard to create a series of large-scale simulations that cover a wide range of parameter space, including dark energy models, modified gravity theories, neutrino masses, and primordial non-Gaussianity.
In addition, we plan to provide various observational datasets that can be compared with simulation outputs using standard techniques such as cross-correlation functions or likelihood analysis.
The Cosmic Encoding Comparison Project is funded by the Astrophysics Theory Program of NASA, with the funding number NNX09AC84G.
The Axion Dark Matter Experiment (ADMX) aims to search for dark matter in the form of axions, which are hypothetical particles predicted by theories beyond the Standard Model.
The ADMX experiment consists of two main components: an antenna and a microwave cavity system that can be tuned over a wide frequency range.
In this paper, we present the results obtained from the first phase of the experiments using data collected from September 2005 to March 2007.
We report the constraints on the coupling strength between axions and photons, as well as the constraints on axion mass generated through Primakoff conversion in a strong magnetic field.
These results represent an increase of more than an order of magnitude compared to the previous experimental limits.
This work was carried out by Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory under contract DE-AC52-07NA27344 with the support of the U.S. Department of Energy.
The Axion Dark Matter Experiment aims to directly search for dark matter existing in the universe in the form of axion particles.
The experiment mainly consists of two parts: an antenna and a microwave resonator system, which can be tuned over a wide frequency range.
In this paper, I will discuss the recent results we obtained in the first phase of the experiment.

We report the detection of HCN (1-0), HNC (1-0), and CH3CN (5-4) line emissions in the nuclear region of the nearby Seyfert 2 galaxy NGC 4418, located at a distance of 20 Mpc, with luminosities exceeding 10^7 Lsun.

The observed luminosity is comparable to that of a super bright infrared galaxy, but the ratios between these spectral lines indicate that this is not a source dominated by an active galactic nucleus (AGN).
On the contrary, we propose that the high-excitation molecular gas may be related to the recent outbursts of young massive stars triggered by tidal effects and/or mergers.
We also found a compact radio continuum source at the center of the Milky Way, which is consistent with previous observations.
This suggests that there may be a deeply embedded active galactic nucleus (AGN) within a few hundred parsecs of the center.
These results provide us with new insights, elucidating how these powerful sources formed in the early stages of galaxy evolution.

We study the gravitational wave signals in chaotic systems using a point mass model and its surrounding accretion disk, which is one of the most promising candidates for gravitational wave sources in astrophysics.

We demonstrate that such a system produces two types of gravitational waves: the first type comes from the orbital motions of binary star systems, with peaks in its spectrum at integer multiples of the orbital frequency.
The second type originates from the spiral structure formed on the surface of the accretion disk due to the tidal interactions between the central black hole and the surrounding material.
Its spectrum does not have obvious peaks, but consists of many frequencies whose amplitudes decrease as the frequency increases.

Furthermore, we found that when the spin parameter of the central black hole is sufficiently large (a > 0.9), the amplitude of the second type of gravitational waves can be much greater than that of the first type of gravitational waves.
This indicates that if the signal-to-noise ratio is sufficiently high, the detection rate of gravitational waves may strongly depend on the spin parameters of the source.
We analyzed the evolution of early-type galaxies (ETGs) in hydrodynamical cosmological simulations, focusing on their formation history and internal structure at redshift z = 0.
We found that the predecessors of ETGs are typically gas-rich systems with higher star formation rates (SFR), which evolve into red sequence objects through dry mergers.

In addition to this primary channel for the formation of external early-type galaxies (ETGs) through significant mergers, we also indicate that smaller mergers can significantly promote the growth of massive external early-type galaxies by introducing fresh cold gas.
Our results indicate that both processes play a significant role in shaping the observed characteristics of local early-type galaxies.
This is consistent with recent observational studies showing that most massive early-type galaxies (ETGs) have experienced multiple merger events throughout cosmic time.
Keywords: galaxy evolution, galaxy morphology, galaxy scaling relations, galaxy clusters, semi-analytic models, fluid dynamics, dark matter.

We propose an effective method to maintain the conservation of total energy and linear momentum in molecular dynamics (MD) simulations by introducing two types of potential energy: one used during the MD run and the other used only when calculating the forces on particles at each time step.
The potential energy of the latter type is disabled after calculation to avoid affecting subsequent molecular dynamics trajectories.
We demonstrate how to implement this scheme into existing molecular dynamics code with minimal modifications.
In addition, we demonstrate its effectiveness through several examples, including liquid argon, water clusters, and carbon nanotubes.
Our results indicate that our new scheme retains energy and momentum very well without any additional computational cost, compared to traditional schemes.
This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China, with grant numbers 10874145 and 10934011.
Keywords: Conservation of energy and momentum; Switching potential; Molecular dynamics

We reported on the Langmuir-Blodgett (LB) deposition technique, which uses an aqueous dispersion containing surfactants and sodium dodecyl sulfate as a dispersing agent to prepare highly ordered, densely packed vertically aligned single-walled carbon nanotube films on solid substrates.

The LB technique is used to transfer these films onto various substrate materials, such as silicon wafers, quartz slides, glass cover slips, gold-coated glass cover slips, and glass cover slips with indium tin oxide coatings.
We also demonstrated that this method can be extended to patterned growth by selectively transferring the thin film onto areas defined by the photoresist pattern.
These results are important for the development of new applications based on carbon nanotubes.

Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were discovered about ten years ago. Due to their unique physical properties, such as high electrical conductivity, mechanical strength, thermal stability, and chemical inertness, they have attracted widespread attention, making them promising candidate materials for many potential applications, including field emission devices, sensors, and optoelectronic devices, among others.
However, most of their practical applications require carbon nanotube networks with controllable orientation and density.
In recent years, several methods have been developed to prepare ordered carbon nanotube films.
Among these techniques, Langmuir-Blodgett (LB) deposition has become one of the most powerful methods.
The process involves expanding a monolayer of amphiphilic molecules at the air-water interface and then vertically immersing a hydrophobic substrate into the aqueous subphase.
By repeating the above steps, a multilayer film composed of closely packed carbon nanotubes (CNTs) can be obtained.

Compared to other methods, LB deposition has many advantages, such as precise control over layer thickness, ease of creating large area uniform films, and the possibility of fabricating patterned structures.

We report on infrared spectral observations of the nearby late-type galaxy NGC 3621 conducted using the Infrared Spectrograph (IRS) on the Spitzer Space Telescope, known to host a supermassive black hole at its center.

We present the results of the search for compact binary merger (CBC) gravitational wave signals using data collected during the third and fourth science runs (S3, S4) of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO).

We use two different search methods to look for CBCs: one is an unmodeled matched filtering method that is sensitive to all possible source directions; the other is a model template method based on the post-Newtonian expansion of general relativity.
The latter method has higher sensitivity but only covers certain areas of the parameter space.
From this work, we report the upper limit of the rate density of CBC events as a function of the chirp mass and total mass.

We study the dynamics of free fermions hopping between various nodes in an arbitrary connected graph, with hopping not limited to nearest-neighbor transitions.
We demonstrate that this system is equivalent to a set of independent random walks that evolve in parallel and interact through pairwise collisions at the vertices.

The collision rate depends solely on the number of particles present at each vertex; for graphs without cycles or multiple edges (such as trees), the collision rate is zero, but in other cases, it can be arbitrarily large.
This model exhibits interesting behavior, including anomalous diffusion and superdiffusion, even when all rates are equal.

Since 1984, the European Commission has funded research by universities, public research institutions (PRIs), and private companies through its Framework Program for Research and Development (FP).
The Fifth Framework Programme (FP5) was implemented from 1998 to 2002 and successfully brought together researchers from across Europe to collaborate on large projects with industrial partners.
This article describes how this collaboration works, while also examining a project of this kind—the Wireless Communications Excellence Network (NEWCOM#).
NEWCOM# has gathered over 100 academic and industrial organizations from across Europe to form a comprehensive research consortium that develops new technologies for wireless communication systems.
It is shown here that the success of NEWCOM# can be attributed to three main factors:

Firstly, it has a clear vision of the goals that need to be achieved; secondly, there is a close connection between academia and industry; thirdly, it benefits from a supportive policy environment within the European Union.

The authors describe how they created a form of artificial life that can self-assemble into a structure resembling a fruiting body of slime mold (Dictyostelium discoideum), commonly referred to as "dictyos."
These coenobia are composed of thousands of the same cells connected by elastic threads and can grow in petri dishes with added nutrients.
It has been proven to be able to grow and divide indefinitely without any external control signals (such as hormones).
This work was completed at the Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering at Harvard University.
Self-assembly refers to the spontaneous organization of matter into ordered structures, such as crystals, snowflakes, and biological entities like bacterial colonies and animal tissues.
In this study, we report our efforts in creating a synthetic multicellular system capable of autonomous growth and division through self-assembly.
We designed a minimal cell that is based on a spherical water-in-oil emulsion droplet, containing a single mic tubular cytoskeleton inside and surrounded by a lipid membrane.

These cells can attach to each other through flexible polymer linkages and assemble into three-dimensional aggregates called "dictyos," which are similar to the fruiting bodies formed by the social amoeba Dictyostelium discoideum.
Our results indicate that these simple cellular units can autonomously organize into complex three-dimensional shapes, reminiscent of natural systems.
The formation of dipoles in self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) on metal surfaces was studied using scanning tunneling microscopy/spectroscopy (STM/STS).
SAM consists of octadecanethiol, with its terminal groups containing one or two thiocyanate groups, which are known to form a strong dipole moment when adsorbed onto a gold substrate.
We found that the presence of these strongly polar groups leads to significant changes in the electronic structure of self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) compared to non-polar alkane chains.
Specifically, we observe the transfer of molecular states to higher energy levels, as well as a reduction in their spatial extension in the direction perpendicular to the surface.
These effects can be explained by a simple model based on the electrostatic interactions between the molecule and the substrate.
Our results demonstrate how chemical functionalization enables the modulation of the properties of organic films deposited on metal surfaces.
The formation of dipoles at the interface of alkanethiol self-assembled monolayers and Ag(111) has been studied using scanning tunneling microscopy/spectroscopy (STM/S).
SAM is prepared by chemisorbing octadecanethiol with a terminal thiocyanate group on Ag(111), forming a film with a large dipole moment per unit area.
The STM image displays an ordered structure separated by bright protruding lines and darker regions.
The STS measurements show that as one moves from the center of the line to the edge, the molecular states shift to higher energy values.
The effect is attributed to the electric field generated by the dipole layer.

The thermal stability and melting behavior of metal single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) were studied using an effective tight-binding molecular dynamics simulation method and the Tersoff potential function.
The results indicate that single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) can melt in the temperature range of 2000 to 3000 K, depending on their diameter.
The research found that for zigzag and armchair type tubes, the melting temperature increases as the diameter decreases.
In addition, research indicates that the melting process involves two stages, in which the tube wall first becomes disordered, followed by the formation of a liquid structure inside the tube.

Finally, we found that the melting point of single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) has a strong relationship with the chirality index n-m. For example, when n-m changes from 0 to 1 or -1, the melting point of zigzag SWCNTs rises rapidly.
Keywords: thermal stability, melting behavior, carbon nanotubes

We proposed an analytical model for calculating the aperture efficiency of a reflected antenna using a circularly polarized feed source. This model is based on ray tracing of the feed horn optics and physical optics (PO) on the aperture surface.
The PO method calculates the electric field distribution on the aperture surface by solving Maxwell's equations using Green's functions.
We indicate that this method can be applied to any type of feed horn, including corrugated conical horns or dual-polarized log-periodic dipole arrays.

The motivation for this work comes from our recent study of the aperture efficiency of two different types of antennas at 1.4 GHz: one is a single dish radio telescope equipped with a corrugated conical feedhorn, and the other is a multi-antenna interferometer composed of eight log-periodic dipole array elements.
In both cases, we found that the numerical results obtained using our new model closely match the experimental data.

We report an unexpected temperature inversion phenomenon that occurs between the two components of a brown dwarf eclipsing binary system. We discovered this phenomenon through infrared photometric measurements and spectral data obtained from the Spitzer Space Telescope (Werner et al., 2004) and the Gemini Observatory (Gemini North).
The main component is cooler than the secondary component by about 300 K at optical wavelengths, but warmer than it by about 100 K at near-infrared wavelengths.
We found that if both stars are affected by the radiation from their common accretion disk, this temperature inversion phenomenon can be explained.
This discovery suggests that the disks around young, low-quality celestial bodies may be more complex than previously thought.

Keywords: accretion disk, inverse P-Cygni profile, irradiation, low-mass stars, near-infrared spectroscopy, luminosity variations, stellar radius, temperature inversion, young stars

1 Introduction  
An important goal in understanding planet formation is to determine what happens during the early stages of planet formation in the protoplanetary disks around young stellar systems.
A key question is whether these disks will evolve into planetary systems similar to our own solar system.
To answer these questions, it is necessary to study individual cases of young protoplanetary disks, as they evolve over time.
However, it is difficult to directly observe the inner regions of these disks because most young stars are deeply embedded in dense molecular clouds.
Fortunately, some young stars are surrounded by optically thin dust, which allows us to detect the physical conditions near the central celestial body through scattered light.

These so-called transitional disks show evidence of clearing a large amount of material within a few astronomical units of the central star, while still retaining a significant amount of gas at greater distances (Strom et al., 1989).
Skrutskie et al., 1990; Calvet et al., 2002; Muzerolle et al., 2003; Sicilia-Aguilar et al., 2006; Espaillat et al., 2007.
Some studies suggest that the outer edges of transitional disks are sculpted by intense ultraviolet radiation-driven photoevaporation winds, which originate from nearby celestial bodies.

The ability to identify individual nanoparticles is crucial for understanding their properties, but this task may face challenges due to the high structural similarity between different types of particles.

In this review, we discussed recent advancements in the characterization of nanoparticles using scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) techniques, which can provide information about chemical composition and structure at atomic resolution.
We also emphasized some challenges faced by these methods and possible solutions.
Finally, we outline the current applications of the STEM-based methods for identifying nanoparticles and suggest directions for future research.
Keywords: Nanoparticles, characterization, transmission electron microscopy, scanning transmission electron microscopy, atomic resolution, structure, chemical composition.

In the past decade, the ability to identify individual nanoparticles has become increasingly important, as it allows researchers to associate specific physical or chemical properties with the size, shape, surface chemistry, and crystal phase of the particles, all of which are believed to affect the performance of many materials.

However, despite significant progress made in recent years, there remains considerable uncertainty regarding how to combine multiple experimental parameters into a single descriptor to best characterize nanoparticles.

This issue mainly arises because nanoparticles often have similar compositions and/or structures, making it difficult to distinguish them solely based on elemental analysis or conventional imaging techniques (such as bright field transmission electron microscopy or scanning electron microscopy).
We study the elastic modulus and its fluctuations of frictionless spheres in dense disordered packing through molecular dynamics simulations.
We found a strong correlation between the shear modulus and the bulk modulus with the local coordination number z(r) at the particle contact point r.
The relevant function C(z1, z2) = ⟨K⟩δ[z1 − z2] decays exponentially for large |z1 − z2|, where K represents the shear modulus or bulk modulus.
This index decay can be explained by an effective medium theory that takes into account the correlations between adjacent contacts.
In addition to this short-range behavior, we observe that when |z1 − z| is small, it follows a power-law tail ∝ (z1 − z2)⁻².⁵.
These results indicate that the elastic modulus of disordered packing can be described as a random variable, whose probability distribution depends on the local packing geometry.
We study the dynamics of string cosmology with non-trivial Moussoulou potentials, focusing on their chaotic behavior.
We demonstrate that for certain categories of potential, there are regions where trajectories can be trapped by unstable fixed points or periodic orbits.
In these cases, we find that the system is not ergodic, but instead has an infinite number of attractors, which correspond to different values of the Hubble parameter H(t).
The existence of such attractor solutions may have significant implications for the evolution of our universe.
For example, this may explain why the present value of H(t) differs so greatly from the initial value at t = 0.

We present the optical and near-infrared photometry of supernova 2006bp, which was discovered on September 24, 2006, by amateur astronomer Brian Puckett in NGC 6946 (Puckett et al., 2007).
This supernova is located at an exceptionally distant location in its host galaxy, with a recession velocity of about 1000 kilometers per second.
We found that the light curve can be well fitted with a model consisting of three components: shock breakout radiation, luminosity driven by radioactive decay, and dust extinction.
Using this model, we derived physical parameters such as the progenitor radius, mass loss rate, and explosion energy.
Our results are consistent with studies of other Type II supernovae, but suggest that the initial mass of the progenitor star is lower than previously estimated.
This may indicate that there is greater diversity among the sources of Type II supernovae than previously recognized.
Apart from these findings, our observations provide new insights into the shock explosion physics and early evolution of Type II supernovae.

We reported the maser emissions of water vapor (H2O) and silicon monoxide (SiO) directed towards the central star of the protoplanetary nebula OH231.8+4.2, which is associated with the infrared source IRAS 18286-1231.

The H2O maser distribution is located in a region with a diameter of approximately 0.1 arcseconds around the star, with a speed range relative to the systemic velocity of the nebula from -40 to +20 kilometers per second.
We detected an SiO maser source only on one side of the celestial body, with a radius of 0.05 arcseconds and a velocity range of -50 to -30 kilometers per second.
These results indicate that H2O masers trace the shocked gas near the surface of the star, while SiO masers originate from the material flowing out along the polar axis.
This work was supported by the Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research from the Japanese Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (Grant Number: 15740160).

We present the results of the first phase of an unbiased survey of high-mass protostars (HMPSs) using the red MSX source (RMS) database and the NRAO 12-meter telescope at Kitt Peak Observatory in Arizona.
The sample includes all sources associated with radio emissions that have infrared excess, located within the Galactic latitude range of |b| < 100 Msun.
They provide evidence of bipole outflow activity and downward motion.

We present the long-term monitoring results of the anomalous X-ray pulsar 4U0142+61 from the Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer (RXTE) proportional counter array and all-sky monitor, which is one of the most active accreting neutron stars in our Milky Way galaxy.
The source observed for over 10 years between February 1996 and December 2007.
We found that the pulse period exhibits significant variations on the time scale from days to months.
In addition, we have detected several significant outbreaks lasting up to 100 days.
The characteristics of these outbreaks are an increase in intensity and hardness ratio.
During these outbreaks, the rotation rate significantly increased compared to before or after.
This indicates that when a star undergoes such an eruption, the magnetic field strength on its surface increases.
Keywords: Accretion Disk - Neutron Star - Outburst

The PE process is used to create optical waveguides in the substrate that have low loss, high refractive index contrast, and significant nonlinearity.

This work represents a step towards achieving on-chip integrated manufacturing of electrically tunable photonic circuits on an insulator.

Keywords: stellar wind, radiation hydrodynamics, line-driven wind, porosity, agglomeration. Massive stars release mass and form stellar winds through the action of radiative pressure on spectral lines (Castor et al., 1975; Abbott & Lucy, 1985).
To understand the structure of these winds, it is necessary to solve the coupled equations of radiative transfer and fluid dynamics simultaneously.

However, the multi-scale nature of the problem—both spatially and temporally—makes numerical solutions extremely difficult, requiring very high-resolution grids to accurately resolve all relevant scales.
Therefore, most previous studies have adopted simplified radiative transfer or hydrodynamic treatments, but have not combined the two.

For example, some authors assume that stellar winds are composed entirely of optically thin gas (e.g., Friend and Castor, 1983), while others use simple formulas regarding the radial dependence of optical depth (e.g., Pauldrach et al., 1986), and even completely neglect the effects of opacity (e.g., Lamers and Cassinelli, 1999).

Other authors simplify assumptions about the flow itself, such as assuming spherical symmetry (e.g., Puls et al., 1996), steady-state (e.g., Owocki et al., 1988), and/or stationarity (e.g., Runacres and Owocki, 2002).

We have used data from the Planck satellite experiment to impose constraints on neutrino mass, mixing angles, and interaction models.

We use measurements of the temperature anisotropy power spectrum of the cosmic microwave background radiation to constrain cosmological parameters, including the total mass of all three active neutrinos (m), the effective number of relativistic species at recombination (N_eff), and the primordial helium abundance (Y_p).

We propose an analytical model to study the effect of quality load feedback on particle concentration and vorticity in fully developed turbulence.
The cascading process is modeled through a set of coupled ordinary differential equations, which are derived based on dimensional analysis and the Kolmogorov similarity hypothesis.
We indicate that the presence of particles can significantly affect the energy transfer rates between different scales as well as the dissipation rates at small scales.
In particular, we found that when there is significant quality loading feedback, the total energy quantity decreases when transitioning to smaller scales.
This result indicates that the presence of heavy particles may lead to a reduction in turbulence mixing efficiency.
Ultimately, our results also indicate that as the Stokes number increases or the initial volume fraction of the particles increases, the effect of mass loading feedback becomes more pronounced.
Our research findings provide useful insights for understanding how heavy particles influence the dynamics of fluid flow.

We studied the properties of an arbitrary number N of boson-Einstein condensates (BECs) that are confined by harmonic oscillators and exposed to disordered external potentials.
We indicate that for any intensity of disorder, there is always a finite atomic fraction localized at each lattice site.

As the disorder increases, the localization length decreases; however, even when the disorder becomes very large compared to the atomic interaction energy, it still retains its macroscopic characteristics.
This result holds in both one dimension and high dimensions.

Our results provide a microscopic understanding for recent experiments on ultracold atomic gases conducted in optical lattices.

We proposed a Hamiltonian formulation of general relativity that includes matter fields on arbitrary spacetime manifolds, covering both classical and quantum aspects.
The basic idea is to use ADM decomposition to separate the metric into spatial and temporal components, as well as time dilation and displacement functions.
We then introduce the canonical momenta conjugate to these variables and use these momenta to construct the primary constraints of the theory.
These constraints generate transformations, under which all physical quantities can remain invariant.
In order to obtain the correct degrees of freedom, we must impose secondary constraints to eliminate non-physical modes.
Finally, we perform canonical quantization, promoting the phase space variables to operators acting on wave functions defined in superspace (the space of all possible metrics).
This leads us to the Wheeler-DeWitt equation, whose solutions can be interpreted as the probability amplitudes between different states of the universe.
We also discussed how this method can be applied to inflation models.

We proposed an open-source framework called Bubblesched, which allows the construction of portable thread schedulers for heterogeneous multi-processors (HMPs).
The main idea is to use bubbles as scheduling units and apply a set of rules to schedule them at different levels of the HMP hierarchy.
We have implemented two schedulers: one based on work stealing and the other based on load balancing.
These two schedulers can operate efficiently on top of Bubblesched without any modifications.

Our experimental results show that when running parallel applications with fine-grained tasks, the performance of these two schedulers improves by up to 3 times compared to state-of-the-art solutions.

We propose an open-source framework called Bubblesched: it allows for the construction of portable thread schedulers for heterogeneous multi-processors (HMPs) and enables efficient operation on them without any modifications.
The framework treats the foam as a scheduling unit and schedules it at various levels of the HMP hierarchy according to a set of rules.
We have implemented two schedulers: one based on preemptive work and the other supported by load balancing.

We propose a decision tree learning method that leverages views of the data to enhance efficiency and scalability.
The proposed method is based on the idea of utilizing multiple perspectives, with each perspective capturing different aspects or features of the same dataset.
We demonstrate how to achieve this by defining a set of views for each node in the decision tree model during learning.
These views are then used as input for a modified version of the standard ID3 algorithm, which is used to learn decision tree structures.
Our experimental results indicate that there are significant improvements in both accuracy and execution time compared to existing methods.
Decision trees are widely used in various fields such as classification, regression analysis, clustering, and association rule mining due to their simplicity and effectiveness.
However, they have two main drawbacks: (1) high computational cost; (2) poor scalability.
Specifically, the number of possible partitions for any given internal node grows exponentially with the size of the training samples of its parent node.
This makes it difficult to effectively design large decision trees.
To address these issues, we propose a new method called Relational View-based Decision Tree Learning (RV-DTL).
RV-DTL is built on the concept of multi-view learning, where each view captures certain aspects of the original data.
More specifically, our method defines a set of views for each internal node in the decision tree being constructed.
Each view corresponds to a specific subset of features that are associated with the corresponding nodes.

Then, RV-DTL does not build the entire decision tree from scratch, but rather starts from small subtrees with leaf nodes as the roots and gradually expands towards the root until all leaf nodes are covered.
In each expansion step, RV-DTL selects the best partition among the available options based on the information gain criterion.
Finally, the final decision tree is constructed by merging.

The coulomb drag effect refers to a phenomenon where one type of charge carrier transfers energy to another type of carrier through the exchange of virtual phonons, resulting in the current in the second type of carrier moving in the opposite direction to its own motion.
In this work, we studied the Coulomb drag phenomenon between two layers of graphene, which are separated by a dielectric spacer layer and are influenced by different gate voltages.
We found that for small gap distances (less than 10 nanometers), there is a significant deviation compared to the predictions of the standard theory based on bulk materials.
These deviations are caused by the presence of transient modes with strong coupling to low-energy charge carriers.
For larger separations, these effects become negligible, as expected.
The results presented here provide useful information on how to use graphene layers to design devices such as transistors or thermoelectric generators.

We present the results of an analysis aimed at determining whether physical veto measures can be part of a pipeline to reduce false alarms when searching for gravitational waves (GWs) from binary black hole mergers and other astrophysical sources.
We used the data collected during the fifth scientific run of the LIGO detector, which took place from September 2005 to January 2007.
The search pipeline is based on matched filtering, and the template waveform is generated using the high-order post-Newton expansion up to 3PN order.

In addition to applying standard cuts on the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), we also implemented two different types of physical vetoes: 1) vetoing events with SNR exceeding a certain threshold when they occur simultaneously in multiple detector stations; 2) vetoing events that have evidence of power exceeding the background noise level in frequency bands below 100 Hz or above 1000 Hz.
In each type of veto right, we define a set of parameters to control its validity.
Using these parameters, we conduct a Monte Carlo simulation to study how the veto operation effectively rejects simulated signals that inject real detector data.
Our main results indicate that two types of physical vetoes significantly enhance our ability to detect gravitational wave signals while maintaining a low false positive rate.

Using the data provided by the seventh data release of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS DR7), we proposed new constraints on the merger rate density and mass ratio distribution of luminous red galaxies (LRGs).
We used these results to impose limits on the number of massive dark matter halos that are independent of the large-scale redshift (LRG) hosts in the local universe.

The halo occupation model we adopted is based on the extended halo occupation distribution proposed by Zheng et al. (2005), which allows us to simultaneously constrain the average occupation function and its scatter at fixed luminosity, as well as the proportion of satellite galaxies that have recently accreted onto their host halo.
Our analysis indicates that there are a large number of massive halos in our sample volume that are not occupied by Luminous Red Galaxies (LRGs).
This result indicates that either many of the highest mass halos formed early in the history of the universe, or they only contain low-mass galaxies.

We report the discovery and characterization of an unresolved binary star system, which consists of two late-type dwarfs, SDSS J080531.8+481233.0AB (hereinafter referred to as J0805+4812).

The primary component is classified as a T6p-type dwarf, with a mass of about 70 times that of Jupiter, while its companion has been identified as a cold brown dwarf candidate with a temperature between 1000-2000 K. We used high-resolution near-infrared spectra obtained from the Gemini Observatory to confirm that these two components are gravitationally bound.
Our analysis shows that this celestial body is one of the heaviest known binaries composed of two low-mass objects.

We introduced the discovery and characteristics of a new unresolved binary star system, which consists of two late-type dwarfs, SDSSJ080531.8 + 481233.0 AB (hereinafter referred to as J0805+4812; see Figure 1).

The main component is classified as a T6p-type star based on spectral analysis, with a mass of about 70 Jupiter masses, while its companion has been preliminarily identified as a candidate for a cool brown dwarf with a temperature range between 1000 and 2000 K.

We analyzed the Bondi accretion rate of primordial black holes (PBHs) during the radiation-dominated era and considered the effects of pressure and viscosity on gas flow.

We found that for primordial black holes (PBH) with a mass \( M \gg 10^{10} \) grams, the Bonnet radius is much larger than the Schwarzschild radius, so the standard Bonnet-Hoyle-Littleton formula can be used to calculate the accumulation rate.
In small mass primordial black holes (PBHs) with mass M < 10^(10)g, we use numerical simulations to determine the time-varying accretion rate.
The results were compared with those obtained under the assumption that the gas has negligible pressure or viscosity.
In addition, we take into account that the accumulated gas may effectively cool through bremsstrahlung radiation before reaching the central black hole.
Finally, we discussed how our results would affect the abundance of primordial black holes (PBHs) at different redshifts.
We analyzed the chemical equilibrium and non-equilibrium processes occurring in the atmospheres of substellar mass objects (SMBOs).

We have developed a new method to calculate the deviation from chemical equilibrium, based on the assumption that at any given point in the atmosphere, all substances are in a state of local thermodynamic equilibrium.
This method allows us to calculate the abundance of different molecular species as a function of the height of the photosphere.
The results indicate that significant deviations from chemical equilibrium may occur even when the gas temperature is much higher than the dust temperature.
Specifically, we found that the concentration of carbon monoxide may have decreased by several orders of magnitude compared to the abundance predicted by the chemical equilibrium model.
These findings suggest that possible non-equilibrium effects should be considered when interpreting the spectra of SMBO observations.
Keywords: chemical equilibrium; dust particles; local thermodynamic equilibrium.
The multiple fractal attributes of human heartbeat have been studied by many authors, but most research focuses on short time series (usually less than one hour).

From this work, we studied the scale properties of long-term electrocardiogram (ECG) recordings during sleep in healthy subjects, using wavelet transform to calculate the singular spectrum f(α), which characterizes the multifractality present in each signal.
We found that the characteristics of all signals exhibit a wide range of exponent α, indicating strong multifractality.
In these spectra, the width Δα decreases with the increase of the recording length T, following the relationship Δα ~ T^(-1/2) for cases where T is greater than 10 hours.
This indicates that when considering longer recordings, the electrocardiogram becomes more monofractal in nature.
Finally, we demonstrate how to use our results to detect pathological changes in heart rate variability associated with congestive heart failure.

These results are very consistent with those obtained by analyzing the Bethe ansatz equation.
Finally, we discussed how our results can be generalized to higher dimensions.

In this work, we study the existence and stability of so-called wormholes in the spacetime described by the exact solutions corresponding to the gravitational field generated by a spherically symmetric body.
This solution corresponds to the case of the simplest stationary black hole.
We demonstrate that these wormholes are stable under specific conditions involving the cosmological constant.
We have also proposed a new category of exact solutions for the Klein-Gordon-Einstein problem in a homogeneous isotropic space.
These solutions correspond to steady-state scalar waves located locally around a singularity, where there is an infinite scalar energy density at that point.
Finally, we briefly discussed how these solutions can be used as coherent gravitational radiation sources.
We propose a logic for reasoning about the reachability properties on linked data structures, which are graphs with labeled nodes and edges that can be traversed using Web Link Language (WLL).
WLL is an extension of RDFS that allows specifying how applications can create or modify links between resources.

We demonstrated how our logic can be used to express important query categories, such as finding all paths between two given nodes in linked data, calculating the distance between them, checking whether there exists at least one path between them, etc., and we proved its decidability.
Finally, we provided algorithms to evaluate these queries under certain constraints.
Our results have been implemented in the LOD2 system.

Carbon monoxide (CO) is one of the most abundant molecules in the universe, and its detection has been widely used in the past few decades to study the properties of cold neutral atoms and molecular gas in galaxies at different time periods in the universe.
However, carbon monoxide (CO) is difficult to observe directly due to its lack of an electric dipole moment, and its radiation is very weak.

We have proposed a new construction of low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes, which demonstrates good performance on both binary symmetric channels (BSC) and additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channels. The code is combined with Slepian-Wolf or Wyner-Ziv compression to achieve a distributed lossy data storage system that reaches capacity over noisy channels.

We demonstrate how to use these LDPC codes in the context of what's called lossless distributed data storage, by employing them within a framework of error-correcting codes known as rate-less fountain codes.

Finally, we demonstrate how our proposed solution can outperform existing solutions with high efficiency under practical constraints, such as limited field sizes and a finite number of decoding iterations.

We study the Laplace spectrum of complex networks, with particular attention to its relationship with random walk dynamics.
We prove that for any network with n nodes, there are at most 2n non-zero distinct eigenvalues (counting multiplicities).
The bound is tight when applied to trees or complete graphs, differing by at most a constant factor.
For general graphs, we have shown that the upper bound on the number of distinct non-zero eigenvalues is O(n log n).
In addition, we have provided a lower bound, indicating that this estimate cannot be improved by more than a poly-logarithmic factor.
Finally, we provide numerical evidence that real-world networks only have a few distinct non-zero eigenvalues.

These results indicate that the spectral properties of complex networks may not strongly depend on their degree distribution, but rather depend more on other structural features, such as the clustering coefficient.
The analysis proposed here can also be used to derive new bounds on the mixing time of Markov chains defined on these networks.

We have conducted a detailed analysis of the early photospheric evolution of the Nova Scorpii 2004 #1, based on high-resolution optical spectral data obtained from the Very Large Telescope in Chile, using ultraviolet and visible light spectrographs.
This nova was discovered by amateur astronomers on March 31, 2004, when its apparent magnitude reached 8.7.

This is consistent with previous estimates obtained using other methods.

Our best-fit model suggests that the ejected material is primarily composed of oxygen-rich substances mixed with some materials that have undergone the CNO process.
Through addition, we detected strong emission lines from highly ionized species (such as FeXXV/FeXXVI or NeIX/NX).
These lines indicate that during the expansion process, the temperature of the ejecta rises to over 10 million Kelvin.

Quantum mechanics has been successfully applied to many physical phenomena, from atomic physics to condensed matter theory.

Another approach focuses on describing the evolution of open quantum systems, in which the state of the system continuously interacts with the environment.
The latter type of question can usually be expressed as a question about the controllability of quantum dynamical systems.
For example, consider the problem of using laser pulses to guide the states of a two-level atom between different energy levels.
The transcription process is driven by the enzyme RNA polymerase (RNAP), which moves along the template strand of double-stranded DNA and synthesizes mRNA molecules ahead of it.
RNA polymerase is a highly dynamic enzyme that may pause or stall at specific sites during the process of transcribing gene sequences.

From this work, we studied how these pauses affect the overall rate of transcription, using a coarse-grained model to simulate the dynamics of multiple RNAP molecules moving simultaneously on a single DNA strand.
We indicate that the presence of pauses leads to a decrease in the average speed of transcription elongation and a reduction in the total amount of mRNA synthesized per unit time.
The results indicate that the observed differences in transcription rates may be due to variations in RNA polymerase density pausing between genes.

We propose an algorithm for computing the semidefinite representation (SDR) of convex sets in arbitrary dimensions, which is based on solving linear programming with polynomially many constraints and variables.
SDR can be used to solve many NP-hard problems and even undecidable problems by reducing these problems to solvable convex optimization problems.

We demonstrate how this method can be applied to several important computational problems, such as finding Nash equilibria in games, learning graphical models, and approximating mixed-integer programming problems.
Finally, we discuss some open questions related to our work.
The semidefinite representation provides a powerful tool for solving difficult computational problems through convex optimization.

Especially, they enable us to transform difficult problems into manageable convex optimization problems, such as finding Nash equilibria in multi-player games, learning graphical models, and approximating mixed-integer programming problems.

We reported the observation of strong electron-phonon interaction (EPI) in heavily boron-doped epitaxial graphene grown on SiC(0001).

The enhancement of EPI is over an order of magnitude higher than that observed in undoped graphene, which can be attributed to the formation of Dirac points at high doping levels and their associated van Hove singularities near the Fermi level.
This discovery indicates that in doped graphene, the EPI may be tunable over several orders of magnitude through chemical or electrostatic gating.
Graphene has attracted considerable attention due to its unique physical properties, such as extremely high carrier mobility and very large optical nonlinearity.
However, these exceptional characteristics are often accompanied by weak interactions between electrons and phonons, which limit their application in high-speed electronics and optoelectronics.

In this work, we demonstrate that the EPI in heavily boron-doped epitaxial graphene grown by thermal decomposition of SiC can be significantly enhanced, due to the presence of Dirac points and the associated van Hove singularities near the Fermi level (EF).

We indicate that when the Fermi level crosses the Van Hove singularity, the electron-phonon interaction (EPI) increases rapidly, resulting in a significant rise in the electron-phonon scattering rate.
Our results indicate that the EPI in graphene can be electrically controlled through chemical or electrostatic gating, thereby opening up new avenues for novel devices based on graphene.
Graphene is considered to have extremely high carrier mobility 1-4, but relatively small electron-phonon coupling 5-9.
These two competitive effects determine the performance of graphene-based electronic and optoelectronic devices.
For example, a low EPI leads to a slow relaxation rate, which in turn limits the operating speed of graphene transistors.

Rotational measurement (RM) surveys have been widely used to study large-scale magnetic fields in nearby galaxies as well as in distant galaxy clusters.
However, conducting such research in the central region of the Milky Way is challenging due to the strong foreground radiation from ionized gas along the line of sight.

In this work, we report the measurements of the rotation of the extragalactic radio source observed through the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA), as well as an investigation of the large-scale magnetic field in front of the Milky Way center.
Our sample consists of 1253 radio sources, which were selected from the AT20G catalog based on their angular distance from the Galactic center.
Their rotation measurements are based on multi-frequency observations conducted between 2007 and 2010.
The rotation measurement diagram of the results reveals a distinct pattern of alternating positive and negative values in the sky.

After fitting these data points with a simple axisymmetric model, we obtained the best-fit value B = 3 μG, which represents the average magnetic field strength within a radius of 2 kpc centered on the Galactic center.
Beyond this area, the magnetic field strength rapidly decreases to below 1 microgauss. Additionally, there appears to be a systematic axisymmetric deviation around the galactic center.

We present the analysis results of gravitational wave data collected by the LIGO and Virgo detectors during the first observation run (O1) in 2015, which includes two candidate events of binary neutron star mergers.

We use these observations to test the relativity of general relativity against other gravitational theories, which predict deviations from general relativity in high curvature regions (such as near black holes or neutron stars).
Specifically, we consider scalar-tensor theories in which the coupling between the matter field and the metric is realized through a light scalar field.
These theories are inspired by string theory and have undergone extensive research over several decades.
For each event, we perform Bayesian model selection using simulated signals generated from general relativity and several representative scalar-tensor theories.
Our results show that, within the current range of uncertainty, there is no evidence of any deviation from general relativity.
However, this does not exclude all possible relativistic biases; it only excludes certain categories of biases predicted by specific models.

We provide an explanation for the phenomenon of excess gamma-ray emission observed by the Energetic Gamma Ray Experiment Telescope (EGRET) at energies exceeding 10 GeV, which is known as the "GeV anomaly."
We indicate that if there are two populations of pulsars with different magnetic field strengths, this excess phenomenon can be explained.
The first group is composed of young pulsars, whose magnetic fields decay rapidly due to their fast slowdown.
These pulsars produce most of the high-energy photons detected by EGRET.
The second type of pulsars is composed of older pulsars, which have magnetic fields that decay more slowly because their rotation speeds are, on average, slower than those of younger pulsars.
The high-energy radiation produced by this second population is less, but it makes a significant contribution to the total number of pulsars.
Our model predicts that Fermi should detect many new pulsar candidates that have not been seen before.
In addition, we predict that some of these newly discovered pulsars will exhibit higher brightness than other pulsars.

We study how the presence of a central supermassive black hole (SMBH) affects the dynamical evolution and mass loss rate of an open star cluster containing 10,000 stars that is in a state of dynamic equilibrium.

We propose an efficient computational method that calculates the elastic properties, vibrational frequencies, and normal modes of proteins through finite element analysis (FEA).
The proposed method represents each amino acid residue as a node, which is located within a three-dimensional tetrahedral mesh that covers the entire structure of interest.

In this study, we analyzed the stellar mass assembly of over 100,000 massive galaxies selected from the VVDS-02h field, which were observed using the VIMOS spectrograph on large telescopes, with a redshift range of 0 < z < 5.
We use a novel technique that combines photometric redshift and spectral energy distribution fitting to derive accurate galaxy mass estimates over such a wide redshift range.

Our results indicate that the evolution of the average stellar mass density can be divided into two main phases: i) a rapid increase until z ~ 2, and then ii) a slower growth phase that continues to the present day.

This behavior is consistent with previous studies, but our data allow us to investigate in detail how the accumulation of stellar mass varies with different galaxy properties, such as color or morphology.
We studied the escape dynamics of a two-dimensional elastic string influenced by thermal noise under periodic boundary conditions in a potential well.
We found that there are three different mechanisms for the escape process, depending on the depth \( V_0 \) of the potential well.
For smaller V0 values (V0 < Vc), we observe a single exponential decay of the survival probability, which is consistent with the expectation of a first-order phase transition.
Under this mechanism, the average lifespan decreases exponentially as the temperature T increases.
For the intermediate value of V0 (Vc < V0 < Vs), we observe a double exponential decay of the survival probability, indicating the presence of a second-order phase transition.

The average lifespan increases linearly with decreasing temperature when the temperature drops below the critical temperature Tc, where Tc is the critical temperature at which the system undergoes a continuous phase transition into a metastable state.
Finally, at a larger value of V0 (Vs < V0), no escape occurred within our simulation time window.

We present the results of our numerical simulations of magnetized accretion disks. In these simulations, we use the shear box approximation to solve the axisymmetric magnetohydrodynamic equations of the accretion disk, assuming a radial distribution of angular momentum and mass flux.

We found that the magnetic field is amplified through differential rotation, resulting in a large-scale polar field, the intensity of which increases outward, exhibiting a relationship of $(r^{-3/2})$ (where $r$ is the radius).

This leads to an enhanced outward transport of angular momentum on the disk surface compared to relying solely on viscous stress.

We analyzed the gravitational collapse process in the original protostellar system halo, using high-resolution N-body simulations combined with hydrodynamics and radiative cooling.
We found that the density distribution of dark matter halos can be well described by the Navarro-Frenk-White (NFW) profile for all redshifts z < 10.

The NFW concentration parameter c(z) is used to characterize the concentration of halo mass distribution relative to its average density. When the redshift drops below z = 5, its value increases rapidly.
This rapid increase can be explained by the fact that the adiabatic contraction caused by the infalling baryons makes the central region of the halo denser.

We studied the diameter and clustering coefficient of several types of random graphs with power-law degree distributions, including the preferential attachment (PA) networks.
We proved that if the growth rate of PA networks is slow enough, their diameter will be small; this result still holds when we allow multiple edges between nodes.

We present the long-term numerical simulation results of binary black hole (BBH) evolution, including gravitational radiation reaction and general relativity effects such as frame dragging and tidal disruption.
We focus on binary systems with a total mass of \( M = 100-1000M_{\odot} \), which evolve in collisional nuclear environments at high redshifts \( z > 10 \).
Our main goal is to study how dual black holes grow via accretion during their early evolutionary stage when they are surrounded by dense gas clouds.
We specifically study whether these systems can reach a mass exceeding 1000 times that of the Sun before merging within the Hubble time.
The initial conditions of our model are obtained through Monte Carlo sampling of the isolated black hole binary distribution function constructed by Belczynski et al. (2010).
In each model, we conducted several runs starting from different track configurations.
All calculations are based on the assumption of a circular orbit.
We found that most massive binary stars merge within a few hundred million years after formation due to the emission of gravitational waves.

However, some of them are still alive today because they formed in regions where the surrounding gas density exceeds \(10^{9}\) cm\(^{-3}\). These binaries may be detected in future space-based gravitational wave observatories, such as LISA or DECIGO/BBO.

We have detected for the first time the relativistically modulated X-ray flux from the black hole candidate Sagittarius A* at the center of the Milky Way, with data from the Chandra and XMM-Newton Observatories collected between 2000 and 2007.

The observed light curve shows clear periodic declines, with time scales ranging from 20 minutes to several hours, consistent with the general relativistic effects near the event horizon of a supermassive black hole.
We did not find evidence of long-term changes or flare activity in these observations.
These results provide strong support for theoretical models that suggest the emissions are generated by accretion disk instabilities near the last stable orbit close to the central black hole.

We have provided new infrared photometric data for the sample of low surface brightness giant galaxies (LSBGs) from the study by van Dokkum et al. (2015).

LSBGs (Low Surface Brightness Galaxies) have been observed with the Spitzer Space Telescope's Spitzer/IRAC and MIPS cameras, covering the wavelengths of J (1.25 microns), H (1.65 microns), Ks (2.17 microns), 3.6 microns, 4.5 microns, 5.8 microns, and 8.0 microns.

Our results show that, except for one galaxy, all the galaxies have an old stellar population that is primarily dominated by red giants, which are at least 100 million years older than the red giants in typical early-type galaxies.
This is supported by our analysis, which shows that, compared to other types of galaxies, they have very little emission of cold dust.
These findings suggest that most low surface brightness galaxies may have undergone passive evolution over the past several billion years, without significant star formation activity.
We present new observational data of the molecular gas in the central region of the nearby galaxy NGC 891, obtained using the IRAM 30-meter telescope at wavelengths of 1 millimeter and 3 millimeters.
The data reveals a widespread distribution of dense (n(H2) ~ 10^4 cm^-3), warm (T ~ 50K) molecular gas associated with the optical disk of this edge-on spiral galaxy.

We found that the distribution of molecular gas has two different components: one component closely follows the dust lane seen in the visible light image, while the other extends into the surrounding interstellar medium.
The latter part has been detected by other authors before, but our higher resolution data allows us to break it down into individual clouds.
Through addition, we detected multiple compact sources within the plane of the Milky Way, which are likely young star formation regions.
These results indicate that there may be a significant molecular matter reservoir outside the main body of galaxies like NGC 891.
We present the research results on the possible existence of Earth-like planets surrounding Gliese 581, located about 20 light-years away from Earth, and their stability.

We conducted numerical simulations of terrestrial planets under three different hypotheses with varying orbital configurations, with the masses of these planets ranging from 1 to 10 times that of Earth (1-10 M⊕).
"Our calculations indicate that all these systems are dynamically stable over a time scale of more than 100 million years."
The largest planet has an eccentric orbit with an eccentricity e = 0.2, and the distance at periapsis varies between 0.05 AU and 0.15 AU, depending on the initial conditions used.

However, we have discovered another region where two or more Earth-like planets may stably exist.
In this region, one of them could be a super-Earth type planet, with a mass greater than 5 times that of Earth (5M⊕) but less than 8 times that of Earth (8M⊕).

We study the magnetic field amplification in supernova remnants (SNRs) caused by the instability of cosmic ray streaming, which is driven by the anisotropic diffusion of energetic particles along the average magnetic field lines.
We indicate that this process may lead to the levels of magnetic fields observed in young supernova remnants and may explain their origin.
The growth rate of instability depends on the ratio between the relativistic proton spin frequency and the frequency of the plasma waves it excites.
This ratio decreases over time because the number density of particles accelerated in front of the shock wave is gradually increasing.

The results indicate that at a certain distance behind the shock front, the instability of the perturbation will saturate, at which point the magnetic energy density is comparable to the kinetic energy density of the flow.
To estimate the saturation scale, we used an analytical model recently proposed by Bell et al. (2013).
It enables us to calculate the spectrum of amplified magnetic fluctuations generated by the instability of cosmic ray flow.

This trend can be interpreted as the large-scale magnetic field generated by the generator operating at the base of the convection zone becoming more complex during the evolution process of the red giant branch.
Our research results also indicate that the proportion of tilted rotating stars decreases with age.

We study the deviation of the trifold maximum neutrino mixing caused by the breaking of an additional U(1) gauge symmetry at high energy scales due to two Higgs doublets in the Type-II torsion model.
We indicate that this scenario can be realized within the framework of supersymmetric grand unified theories (SUSY GUTs).

We specifically consider the SO(10) supersymmetric grand unified theory model, where the right-handed Majorana mass matrix of the light neutrinos originates from the vacuum expectation values of three paired Higgs fields, which, under SU(5), transform into 10 ⊕ 126 ⊕ 120, while the Dirac mass matrix is generated through Yukawa coupling with the 16-dimensional fermionic states.

We present the analysis results of all available comet dust tail data, including recent observations from spacecraft and ground-based telescopes.
We found that most of these objects are related to Jupiter family comets (JFCs), which have orbital periods of less than 20 years.

The majority of tail structures we observed are consistent with models where particles are continuously released over timescales ranging from a few months to thousands of years.

We study the general characteristics of discrete choice models with social influence, where agents make decisions based on their private information and the choices made by others in their neighborhood.
We indicate that if there is no correlation between individuals' private signals, then any equilibrium must be symmetric among individuals (i.e., all equilibria are the same after relabeling).
If, on the contrary, there is some positive correlation between individuals' private signals, we prove that there always exists an asymmetric equilibrium.
Finally, for moderate levels of correlation, we provide examples showing that two types of equilibria can coexist.
These results hold true regardless of whether the agents have a common understanding of each other's payoffs.
Our analysis largely relies on the latest developments in global game theory.
The main idea of our approach is to consider the agent's decision-making problem as a two-stage game with nature.
In the first stage, nature selects her signals to be realized; in the second stage, she makes choices based on the signals that have been realized.

We report on the electronic structure and magnetic properties of zigzag graphene nanoribbons (ZGNR) with different edge structures, including hydrogenated ZGNR (H-ZGNR), fluorinated ZGNR (F-ZGNR), oxidized ZGNR (O-ZGNR), and nitrogen-doped oxidized ZGNR (N-ZGNR).
We found that all these ZGNRs are semimetals except for H-ZGNR, which is a metal.
The band gap of F-ZGNR and N-ZGNR has increased compared to the original ZGNR, which is mainly due to the electronegativity difference between the edge carbon atoms and their neighboring atoms.
On the contrary, when oxygen replaces one or two carbon atoms at each edge, the band gap slightly decreases due to the transfer of charge from oxygen to the neighboring carbon atoms.
Our research findings indicate that introducing oxygen at the edges of zigzag graphene nanoribbons can enhance spin polarization.
We present results regarding the role of the rho meson in describing the pion charge production data obtained with the CLAS detector at the Jefferson Laboratory (JLab).

We reported on the room-temperature ferromagnetism in manganese-doped zinc oxide thin films grown by pulsed laser deposition (PLD).
The Curie temperature for all samples at different doping levels is about 300 K, which is much higher than previously reported values.
We also found that as the applied magnetic field decreases, the magnetization intensity increases linearly and shows a hysteresis loop under low magnetic fields.
These results indicate that the observed ferromagnetic behavior may stem from exchange coupling between local spins, rather than from intrinsic ferromagnetism.

In recent years, an increasing number of people have shown interest in developing new materials for spintronic applications, such as non-volatile storage devices or logic circuits based on manipulating electron spins rather than charge carriers.

ZnO-based DMS has been widely studied due to its wide band gap energy (3.37 eV), large exciton binding energy (60 meV), high transparency, and good chemical stability.

Despite several research groups demonstrating room-temperature ferromagnetic ordering in various types of ZnO-based DMS systems in recent years, most of them exhibit relatively low saturation magnetization.

Gravity is a fundamental force that acts on all matter, manifested as the attraction between these matter bodies.
Newton's theory of gravity can only explain the phenomenon of objects falling towards a single point at the center of the Sun.
Einstein's theory of relativity explains this phenomenon by introducing the concept of curved spacetime.
However, there are other physical phenomena, such as the Casimir effect and electromagnetic radiation pressure effect, that require the introduction of a new dimension in spacetime.
In this paper, we propose to introduce a new spatial dimension to extend classical Euclidean geometry.
We indicate that gravity can be interpreted as a macroscopic manifestation of microscopic effects related to quantum fluctuations of spacetime.

This explanation allows us to restore the theoretical predictions of modern physics regarding celestial dynamics, while also providing a reasonable interpretation for some physical phenomena that have yet to be explained.
We have proposed a new characterization of Schur-class multivariable functions, which are defined as analytic on the open unit ball and satisfy certain growth conditions at infinity.
We demonstrate how to construct such functions using operator-theoretic methods based on the concept of positive kernels.

In particular, we prove that every function in the Schur class can be realized as the transfer function of some stable system, where the state space dimension of the system is equal to its McMillan degree (i.e., the number of poles inside the closed unit disk).
This result is obtained by generalizing a classical theorem proposed by Kalman-Yakubovich-Popov.
Finally, we also provide a necessary and sufficient condition for two given functions to belong to the same Schur class.
These results have applications in control theory and signal processing.

The first star in the universe was born from a primordial gas cloud, which collapsed under its own gravity, forming a dense core that ignited nuclear fusion, ultimately becoming a hot white dwarf.
The largest of these early stars are known as Population III stars (abbreviated as Pop III).

In this work, we demonstrate the results of third-generation star formation obtained from cosmological hydrodynamics simulations through radiative transfer calculations performed on an adaptive mesh refined grid.
We found that third-generation stars can directly collapse to form from gas clouds without heavy metals at a redshift of z > 20.
The mass of these stars is M* = 100 - 1000 M⊙, and their lifespan t < 10 million years.
After consuming all available fuel in the convective shell, they will evolve into black holes or pairing-instability supernovae.
Our results indicate that third-generation stars may have significantly contributed to the reionization of the intergalactic medium at a redshift of z ~ 15.
The Spitzer Bright Galaxy Survey (SBF) is an all-sky survey conducted by the infrared array camera on the Spitzer Space Telescope, at wavelengths of 3.6, 4.5, 5.8, and 8 micrometers.
SBF is designed to provide deep infrared photometric measurements to support and complement existing optical surveys, such as the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.
The dataset contains images taken using IRAC Channel 1 (3.6 microns), Channel 2 (4.5 microns), Channel 3 (5.8 microns), and Channel 4 (8 microns).
Each image was processed using the MOPEX software package developed by the Spitzer Science Center.
These images can be found in the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database (NED).
For more information about this project, please visit http://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/data/SPITZER/docs/sbf/sbf-intro.html.
We present new observational results of polarized radiation from the nearby (7 Mpc) grand design spiral galaxy NGC 6946 using the VLA at a frequency of 1.4 GHz.
The data reveals several interesting features that were not seen in previous studies of the galaxy's radio continuous waves.
We found that the total intensity distribution is primarily dominated by two bright core components, which are located about 2 kpc apart along the axis perpendicular to the main galactic plane.
On the scale of millisecond time delays, the evidence regarding large-scale ordered fields is inconsistent with previous reports.

The polarization vectors in the central region of the galaxy exhibit a clear pattern of alternating directions, which we interpret as a characteristic of the global magnetic field reversal between the two cores.

The rotation measurement diagram shows the annular structure around each nucleus, where the symbol for RM changes, indicating that the magnetic field component in the line of sight direction has altered.
This feature may be related to the so-called depolarization ring observed in other galaxies, but it may also be caused by beam spreading effects or intrinsic Faraday dispersion within the source.
The polarization intensity distribution reveals some extended structures, including a significant southern arm that extends over 10 kpc to the southeast.

We propose an improved equation of state (EOS) for quantum hard spheres to describe dense matter in astrophysics and nuclear physics, which is based on the exact solution of the Schrödinger equation under a repulsive δ function potential.
EOS is obtained by numerically solving the corresponding integral equations using an iterative method.
We also obtained analytical expressions for pressure and energy density as functions of particle number density at zero temperature.

Our results are compared with those obtained previously under various approximations, such as the second-order virial expansion, the Carnahan-Starling approximation, and the Percus-Yevick approximation.
The result is that our new EOS is very consistent with these previous calculations over a wide range of density and temperature.
In particular, it accurately reproduces the low-density limit where the ideal gas law is fully applicable.
Keywords: Equations and States

The purpose of this book is to provide a cutting-edge overview of online condition monitoring and industrial process fault diagnosis, with a particular emphasis on computational intelligence technologies such as neural networks (NNs), fuzzy logic systems (FLS), and evolutionary algorithms (EAs).
This book covers the theoretical aspects and practical applications of these methods.
It also discusses some recent advancements in intelligent sensor technologies, which are crucial for the successful implementation of online condition monitoring schemes.
This book is not only useful for researchers but also very helpful for engineers who want to apply computational intelligence techniques to their own research work.
The content includes: Chapter One: Introduction to Online Status Monitoring.
Chapter 2: Intelligent Sensors and Online Condition Monitoring.
Chapter 3-7: Neural Networks for Fault Diagnosis.
Chapters 8-10: Fuzzy Logic Systems and Fault Diagnosis.
Sections 11-13: Evolutionary Algorithms for Fault Diagnosis.

We analyzed all known short-period cataclysmic variables (CVs) and found that most systems have orbital periods exceeding 3 hours, primarily consisting of SW Sex type stars, while systems with shorter periods tend to be AM Her binaries.
We indicate that this dichotomy is consistent with the evolution of contact variables (CVs) driven by the loss of angular momentum caused by gravitational radiation, as predicted by the theory.

The observed distribution of orbital periods can also be interpreted as indicating that if there exists a minimum period, there will be no variable stars (CVs) below this period due to magnetic braking.
This result is of great significance for our understanding of how cataclysmic variables evolve towards shorter orbital periods.

Cataclysmic Variable Stars (CVs) are binary star systems that interact with a low-mass companion star through Roche lobe overflow, consisting mainly of a white dwarf. They are one of the most extensively studied categories of close binary stars.

They provide a unique opportunity to study various aspects of astrophysics, such as stellar structure and evolution, mass transfer processes, nuclear burning at high temperatures, and relativistic effects near compact objects.
In particular, they provide insights into the formation mechanisms of single and double degenerate white dwarfs, which are the progenitors of Type Ia supernovae.
We studied the origin of the 60 K platform in YBa2Cu3Ox by measuring the changes in specific heat and magnetic susceptibility with temperature, field strength, oxygen content x, and doping level p.
The results show that the 60 K anomaly is due to the antiferromagnetic phase transition that occurs at x=0.6 (TAF = 56 K), but this phenomenon disappears as x increases or p decreases.
We also found that the low-temperature rise observed in C/T and χ(T) is due to the presence of impurity phases that occur when x > 0.65.
The results indicate that the 60K anomaly may be related to the presence of these impurities.
In addition, we found that the high-field magnetization shows a sharp increase below 50 K, indicating that there is another phase transition near this temperature.
This new phase is called the charge density wave state (CDW).
Finally, our data indicate that the CDW state only appears when the sample contains a certain amount of impurities.
