We propose that the dark matter in our universe is composed of particles with milli-charge, which are neutral under electromagnetic interactions but carry a charge of about 10^(-6)e (electron charge).

We demonstrate how to realize this scenario within the framework of the Standard Model by introducing a new gauge boson with a mass of approximately mX ~ 1 TeV/c² into the Standard Model, which is achieved through Stueckelberg extension.
Introducing vector particles of such large mass would lead to modifications of the usual Feynman rules that apply to charged fermions interacting through photons or gluons.

We particularly found that the scattering cross-section mediated by photons between two microcharged particles is suppressed compared to the case where there are no additional heavy vector bosons present.
This suppression leads to a decrease in the number density of late-time milli-charge dark matter particles because their annihilation rate is slower than that of their massless counterparts.
We studied the relaxation dynamics of colloidal suspensions of sheet-like particles through Brownian dynamics simulations and experiments involving polystyrene sheets suspended in water.
We found that the decay of the intermediate scattering function is non-exponential, exhibiting an initial rapid decay followed by a slower decay.
The slowest mode has been identified as the collective diffusion of the suspension.
By comparing our results with those obtained from spherical colloids, we demonstrate how shape anisotropy affects the relaxation process.

Specifically, we observed that the presence of flat surfaces enhances the effects of hydrodynamic interactions between neighboring particles, leading to relaxation times that are faster than those expected based on simple scaling arguments.
Finally, we discuss the potential applications of these systems as model soft matter systems in the study of glass transitions.
Colloidal dispersions are widely used as model systems for understanding phenomena such as phase separation or gel formation.

We analyzed the stability of planetary systems, where protoplanetary embryos evolve under oligarchic domination, meaning they can gravitationally scatter their neighboring embryos away but cannot expel themselves.
We found that this process leads to the rapid growth of the maximum embryo until it reaches its isolation mass (the minimum mass required to achieve uncontrolled aggregation).
The system then evolves into either a single planet or two planets of comparable mass, depending on the proximity of the initial conditions to the instability.
This evolution is very different from the situation where all objects grow simultaneously; in particular, we demonstrate that even with the same initial conditions, multiple stable results may exist.
Our results indicate that the formation of terrestrial planets may have gone through multiple stages, including an oligarchic stage, before ultimately reaching the state we observe today.
In addition, our research provides new insights into the origins of sub-Neptune planets.
The original planetary embryos form in the protoplanetary disks around young stars and undergo mutual gravitational interactions during their growth phase.
These interactions lead to orbital migration and dynamical instability, such as collisions between nearby embryos.
If these processes occur frequently enough, then at the end of the growth phase, there will only be one celestial body left, resulting in a planetary system consisting of just one planet.
However, recent studies indicate that many planetary systems contain multiple planets, suggesting that there must be some mechanism in place to prevent the complete destruction of the system.

Here, we studied the possibility of protoplanetary embryos following a layered evolutionary path, first undergoing layered growth through gravitational scattering, and then entering an uncontrolled accretion phase once the largest embryo reaches its isolation mass.
Through numerical simulations, we demonstrate that this scenario naturally explains the existence of multi-planet systems while also reproducing the characteristics of known exoplanets.

We used two-dimensional fluid dynamics simulations to study the thermal instability and fragmentation phenomena in an initially uniform isothermal cloud embedded in a thermally conducting plasma flow under constant velocity shear.

The initial temperature difference between the cloud and its surrounding environment leads to Rayleigh-Taylor instability at the cloud boundary, which then develops into mushroom-shaped structures; these structures are also subject to Kelvin-Helmholtz mode instability.
We find that these two types of instability can lead to the formation of filaments and clumps in clouds at different timescales, depending on the strength of the magnetic field.
In addition, we indicate that thermal conduction has a minimal impact on the morphology of clouds, but it significantly affects the internal structure of clouds by smoothing density fluctuations.
Finally, we discuss how our results can be used to interpret observations of cometary nuclei and other dense molecular clouds.

The concept of crystal defects has been developed by the Russian school since the 1930s.
The main idea is that any crystal can be regarded as an elastic continuum, but there are some local deviations from its ideal structure, and these deviations are referred to as defects.
In this article, we provide a brief overview of the historical development of solid defect theory.
We also discussed the modern concepts of point defects (dislocations), line defects (twisting), and continuous defects.
Finally, we provided examples of how these ideas can be applied to different physical systems, such as liquid crystals or magnetic materials.
Defects play an important role in many fields of physics, from solid state physics to condensed matter physics, and even in biology.
They naturally occur during the phase transition between ordered states, similar to what happens at the melting point or critical temperature.
For example, they can lead to plastic deformation of metal or glass materials.
On the other hand, defects are the cause of the macroscopic properties of solids (such as electrical conductivity or magnetization).

We propose an algorithm for generating new solutions to the coupled Einstein-scalar field equations by starting from a vacuum solution and adding a scalar field, so that the resulting solution is minimally coupled.
The method can be used to generate exact solutions that are not explicit or only implicitly exist as functions of certain parameters (for example, by solving algebraic equations).

We illustrate our method through several examples, including the Schwarzschild-de Sitter black hole, the Reissner-Nordström-de Sitter black hole, the Kerr-Newman-de Sitter black hole, and the charged expanding black hole.
In particular, we demonstrate how to obtain an explicit expression for the massless limit of these black hole solutions.
Our research results may also have applications beyond gravitational theories; for example, in quantum mechanics, they may provide insights into the structure of bound states.
Introduction: Exact solutions play an important role in theoretical physics, as they allow us to test various physical concepts against concrete predictions.
However, finding exact solutions to physically interesting problems is often very difficult.
For example, after the discovery of general relativity, it took more than 100 years to find the first exact solution for a black hole [1-3].
Even today, there are still many unanswered questions about black holes.
One reason that finding an exact solution is so challenging is that most of the theories of interest do not admit any simple analytical solutions.
When trying to find a solution that describes a system with multiple interacting components (such as black holes surrounded by matter or other fields), another problem arises.
Here, complex differential equations usually have to be solved numerically, which makes it difficult to find all possible solutions, even when the existence of a solution is theoretically guaranteed.

This situation is particularly severe when studying strong coupling phenomena, as the numerical methods become less reliable due to significant corrections from higher-order terms in perturbation theory.
We demonstrated the microlens parallax measurement conducted using infrared observations from the Wide-Field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) for the first time.
We use these data to measure the mass and distance of the two gravitational lensing systems OGLE-2011-BLG-0341L/MOA-2011-BLG-262S and MOA-2012-BLG-0171.
The former is an event in which the source star approaches two lenses; we found that its total mass is 1.4 solar masses and the distance is 4 kiloparsecs.
The latter system consists of three celestial bodies—the lens, its host star, and another distant companion star—all of which are gravitationally bound to each other.
The event of this double lens shows significant deviations from the standard single lens behavior due to the presence of this third celestial body.
Using our new measurement technology, we determined the mass ratio between the lens components and their projected separation in the sky.
The goal is to evaluate the potential use of Monoksa dorsiplana as an alternative biological control agent against the false weevil (Pseudopachymeria sp., family Curculionidae).
The parasite was obtained in the laboratory and released onto P.sp.
Ova produced by female specimens collected at different locations in Brazil, Argentina, and Paraguay.
The egg parasitism rate varies by location, ranging from 0.5% to 88%.
The parasitic eggs hatch within 7 days under controlled conditions.
The male appears first, followed by the female.
The lifespan of females varies with temperature, being 11 to 21 days at 25°C; 14 to 23 days at 20°C; and 16 to 27 days at 15°C.
The female can continue to lay eggs for up to three weeks when feeding on a honey solution.
This species is considered very suitable for mass production because it has a high reproductive capacity and a short life cycle.
It can be successfully applied in integrated pest management programs aimed at reducing the damage caused by this pest.

We found that our standard model, which includes injecting thermal energy into the gas particles surrounding black holes (BH) and the dynamical outflows driven by black hole winds, can reproduce many of the characteristics of giant galaxies observed at z = 0, including their stellar mass function, sizes, morphology, star formation rate, metallicity, and the proportion of cold gas.

Most of these low-quality halos host dwarf galaxies or are satellite galaxies around more massive central galaxies.
We present new spectral observations of eight red giants in the nearby dwarf spheroidal galaxy Leo II (distance = 3 million parsecs).

The range of heliocentric radial velocities we measured is from -150 to +50 kilometers per second.

Using this new data, we have determined that there are no significant rotational or flow movements within the system.
The result supports theoretical predictions based on N-body simulations, which suggest that dark matter halos should be nearly spherical systems.
In addition, our results further confirm that the possibility of Leo II containing an intermediate-mass black hole at its center is not feasible.

We present the results of metal and molecular gas cooling in cosmological hydrodynamic simulations using the Enzo code, focusing on the different numerical schemes used to solve the energy equation (smoothed particle hydrodynamics versus grid-based methods) and the variations in how different physical prescriptions affect stellar formation feedback.
We found that, compared to grid-based methods, SPH codes tend to overestimate the amount of cool gas at high redshifts, which is mainly due to artificial viscous heating.
The feedback model that includes galaxy winds can suppress this effect while removing low-entropy material from the galaxy.
However, we also demonstrate that if these wind models remove too much hot halo gas surrounding the massive halos, they may lead to an underestimate of the total mass fraction of cold gas.

Overall, our results suggest that current advanced galaxy formation models provide reasonable estimates of the global properties of the warm-hot intergalactic medium, but may still lack important physical processes related to the detailed distribution of metals within individual galaxies.

In this work, we consider decoding forwarding (DF) cooperation among nodes in wireless networks and propose an optimal routing algorithm that jointly optimizes the routing from the source to the destination and the cooperative relay path to maximize network throughput.
We formulate this problem as a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) problem, which is NP-hard due to its combinatorial nature.
To efficiently solve this problem, we developed two heuristic algorithms with polynomial time complexity.
The first method uses a greedy algorithm to iteratively select the best path between each pair of source-target pairs until all traffic is routed.
In order to further improve performance, we have also designed another algorithm that uses simulated annealing technique.
A large number of simulation results indicate that the algorithm we proposed can achieve significant improvements over existing solutions.
Index terms - Collaborative communication, optimal routing, simulated annealing, greedy algorithm.

In this article, we propose an autonomous distributed access control scheme to improve the performance and fairness of wireless local area networks (WLANs).
The proposed plan is based on the concept that each site maintains its own queue length information by using the packet arrival time intervals at the physical layer.

We demonstrate through simulation results that our scheme can achieve better throughput than existing solutions while maintaining good fairness among competing sites.

Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is an important evolutionary force that can increase genetic diversity and accelerate evolution, but it also has negative effects, such as disrupting co-adapted gene complexes or introducing harmful mutations into the recipient genome.

Through this study, we explored how horizontal gene transfer (HGT) affects the average fitness of single cells evolving under different environmental conditions, using computational models for the research.
We found that when cells are exposed to fluctuating environments with high-stress events, horizontal gene transfer increases the average fitness.
However, if there are only slight fluctuations, horizontal gene transfer can reduce the average fitness, as it introduces harmful mutations.
Finally, in a constant environment without any external pressures, horizontal gene transfer does not affect the average fitness.
Our results indicate that horizontal gene transfer (HGT) may have played an important role in the early stages of evolution, enhancing the adaptability of life to changing environments.

We found that when we randomly remove a node or remove a node based on its degree, the average path length increases logarithmically with the linear increase in the number of removed nodes.
The increase of this logarithmic series can be explained by considering how the removal of a node affects the shortest paths that pass through it.
The probability that an edge belongs to such a path decreases exponentially as the distance from the deleted node increases.
Therefore, most of the affected edges are those that were close to the node before the node was removed.
These short-range connections form a small-world subnetwork around each deleted node.

I. Introduction

In recent years, there has been a renewed interest in higher-order derivative theories of gravity, primarily driven by their potential role in quantum gravity phenomenology (see, for example), while they also provide interesting alternative scenarios for modified gravity in the context of standard general relativity (GR).

However, despite these efforts, our understanding of the physical consequences of these theories remains incomplete, mainly due to the technical difficulties associated with analyzing their solutions.

One of the main obstacles arises from the fact that the equations of motion derived from these interactions involve derivatives of arbitrary order, making them difficult or impossible to solve analytically.
One way to solve this problem is to expand the field around certain fixed backgrounds and then truncate after expanding the finite terms of the result series.

Although this method can provide useful information about the system dynamics under consideration, it fails to capture important features, such as the feedback effects between different patterns within the same field or the interactions between different fields.

For example, in the context of inflationary cosmology based on higher-order derivative gravity, the truncated perturbative expansion may not accurately reproduce the observed level of primordial non-Gaussianity.
A more systematic approach to dealing with these issues involves using covariant techniques that were initially developed within the framework of general relativity.
These methods enable us to express the equations of motion in a clear and standardized form.

We present images and light curves of the supernova remnant (SNR) associated with type IIb supernova SN2004et from very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) observations at 8.4 GHz. SN2004et exploded on September 24, 2004 UTC in the nearby spiral galaxy NGC 6946.
The radio radiation primarily consists of two bright components, which were observed to be approximately 0.5 arcseconds apart at all observation points between January 2005 and December 2007.
We found that the expansion speeds of these two components are both about 5000 kilometers per second, which is consistent with previous estimates based on single radio telescope data.
However, we also detected significant self-motion of each component during this period, approximately ~1000 kilometers per second.
These results indicate that the age of this supernova remnant is approximately 3 years, allowing us to infer that the distance to NGC 6946 is 4 Mpc.
This value is significantly smaller than the distance of the object estimated using other methods previously.
Our measurements provide new constraints for the core-collapse supernova model.

Finally, we discussed the potential applications of our results in astrophysical phenomena such as gamma-ray bursts.

The variable star single observation project is an open-source software package used for analyzing astronomical data.
It was developed by members of the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics (CfA) in collaboration with researchers from other institutions around the world.

The goal of this project is to provide a single tool that can be used to analyze all types of astronomical datasets, including photometric time series, spectral observations, images, and more, using state-of-the-art techniques such as image subtraction, cross-correlation, period-finding algorithms, and spectral line fitting.
The software is released under the GNU General Public License v3 and can be obtained on GitHub at the following link: https://github.com/VariableStar/one-shot-astro.
One Shot Astro includes several tools that are very useful for quickly and effectively analyzing large amounts of astronomical data.

These tools include one-shot-datacleaner, which performs automatic quality control checks on raw data files; one-shot-mosaic, which creates mosaic images using multiple jittered exposures; one-shot-astrometry, which determines astrometric solutions for a single frame or the entire mosaic image; one-shot-photometry, which measures the flux and/or brightness of stars in the field of view; one-shot-pipeline, which automates the process of combining these different tasks into a pipeline; and one-shot-wikimapia, which allows users to create custom star maps based on their own celestial catalogs.

In addition to these core packages, there are many additional modules available through the one-shot-astro repository, allowing users to conduct more specialized analyses. For example: one-shot-catalog, which provides access to various astrophysical databases through SQL queries; and one-shot-fastphot, which uses machine learning methods to measure celestial objects.

We propose an algorithm that uses three quantum wires and one auxiliary qubit to compute the Jones polynomial. This algorithm is based on the idea that the Jones polynomial can be computed by evaluating the graph's Tutte polynomial at 1.
We demonstrate how this method naturally leads to a circuit with O(n) gates and a depth of O(log n), where n represents the number of crossings in the intersection graph.

The Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) is an ongoing project aimed at mapping the distribution and motion of galaxies, quasars, stars, and other celestial objects in space.
The fourth data release was made public on September 30, 2003.
The fifth data release contains over 100,000 new quasar candidates selected through color criteria from the SDSS imaging survey.
These data also added approximately 20,000 previously known quasars that were not included in earlier releases due to not meeting the criteria for inclusion at that time.

They were all spectroscopically confirmed using observational data from a dedicated 2.5-meter telescope at the Apache Point Observatory near Sacramento, California.

The impact temperature of molybdenum is determined by measuring the resistance of the impacted sample under pressures of up to 1,000 kilobars (1 megabar).
The release temperature is measured using an optical pyrometer, with the sample being heated by laser illumination after undergoing shock at different pressure levels.
The impact generated by the pulse power machine is used to compress the sample material between two electrodes.
The voltage pulses applied to these electrodes cause current to flow through the compressed material, resulting in Joule heating.
The increase in temperature raises the material's resistivity, causing it to expand rapidly when the temperature exceeds the Curie point.
As this expansion occurs, the resistance significantly decreases, resulting in a sharp increase in the current flowing into the sample.
When the current reaches the critical value, the sample explodes, releasing most of the stored energy.
The explosion also destroyed one or two electrodes, so further measurements cannot be carried out until new electrodes are installed.

We study the gauge structure of quantum spin systems with local interactions, which is described by the so-called Kitaev model.
We indicate that the model is equivalent to a lattice gauge theory (LGT) that can be solved exactly, with its action given by a Chern-Simons term.
The equivalence of these two theories allows us to use the powerful techniques developed for LGTs (Lattice Gauge Theories), such as index theorems or localization techniques.

Specifically, we prove that the ground state degeneracy of the Kitaev model on any closed 3-manifold M is equal to the number of independent solutions of certain differential equations known as the Witten equations.
This result can be regarded as a generalization of the Atiyah-Patodi-Singer index theorem to manifolds with boundary.
Finally, using the results above, we derived some exact formulas for the partition function of the Kitaev model defined on surfaces with boundaries.
These formulas generalize Witten's famous formula for the partition function of Yang-Mills fields on Riemann surfaces.

Type I: Its universal cover in \( R \times S^2 \) is homotopy equivalent.

We study the stability characteristics of circumnuclear disks (CNDs) embedded in elliptical galaxies using N-body simulations that include active dark matter halos and stellar components.
We found that CND is generally stable for rod formation under most reasonable disk parameters.

However, we also indicate that if the mass of the central black hole is sufficiently large to dominate the gravitational potential at small radii, it can induce strong stripes and even destroy the entire disk.
This result suggests that the presence of supermassive black holes may be the cause of the nuclear bar structures observed in some nearby elliptical galaxies.

Keywords: gravitational instability; black holes; bar structures; nuclear activity; galaxy evolution; disk galaxies; dark matter halos; stellar dynamics; cosmology.

1. Introduction

Several authors have inferred the existence of nuclear bars based on luminosity data (for example, Laine et al., 2002; Erwin, 2004).
Specifically, Erwin and Sparke (2003) found that about half of the early-type galaxies in their sample have nuclear bars.
These results indicate that nuclear bands play an important role in galaxy evolution.
For example, they can provide energy to active galactic nuclei by allowing gas to flow into the center of the host galaxy (Shlosman et al. 1990).

On the other hand, only a few observational studies have directly detected nuclear bars through high-resolution imaging techniques (such as HST observations) due to the technical challenges associated with resolving the very compact structures in the centers of distant galaxies (Erwin 2004; Sheth et al., 2005).
Therefore, conducting theoretical research on the dynamic behavior of nuclear rods can help us understand how these objects evolve over time.

2 Previous Work  
Some previous research has explored the stability of nuclear bars in elliptical galaxies.
Athanassoula et al. (2005a) conducted numerical experiments in a model that included an active halo and a rigidly rotating disk, adding a rigidly rotating spherical component to represent a bulge.
They indicate that when the mass ratio between the inflated body and the disk exceeds the critical value, the system will become unstable.

We consider the problem of scheduling jobs on parallel machines with preemption and failure characteristics, where each job consists of multiple tasks that must be processed in order by different machines.

We studied the effect of measurement noise on the Markov properties of stochastic processes with continuous state spaces and discrete time steps.

We prove that under certain conditions, if the transition probabilities of a noise process are modified by an exponential factor that depends solely on the noise level, then the noise process remains a Markov process.
This result can be used to derive efficient algorithms for calculating the stationary distribution of such processes.
The results presented here extend the previous work on this topic, which was limited to finite state space models.

In addition, we provide examples to illustrate how our theory applies to several important types of stochastic processes, including diffusion processes, autoregressive moving average (ARMA) processes, and hidden Markov models.

"Measuring micro Calculus is an extension of the standard formalism of quantum mechanics, allowing for measurements of composite systems, and it has been applied in some recent works as well as in this paper."

The main idea of measuring micro-calculus is to consider all possible outcomes of the measurement process as a system being measured in different states, rather than just a single outcome (as von Neumann did).
This method will naturally guide us to consider the collection formed by all possible measurement outcomes, which is referred to as the new state space of the effect algebra.
In addition, measurement calculus provides a way to describe how different measurement processes are combined into more complex measurement processes through so-called instrumental combinations.
Finally, the measurement of calculus also includes a description of what happens when we measure a system where we are uncertain about a state and only know that there is some sort of uncertainty.
The measurement calculus was initially introduced by Aharonov and others, and since then, numerous papers on its properties and applications have emerged.

We present the results of cosmological simulations aimed at studying the formation and evolution of satellite galaxies undergoing tidal stripping in galaxy clusters, which we refer to as "tidal dwarf galaxies" (TDs).
We found that the tidal tail was formed by the gas-rich satellites that were stripped away when they first passed through the cluster's potential well at periastron.
The quality range of the obtained TDs is between 10^8 M_sun and 10^10 M_sun, with a size less than 100 pc and a circular velocity greater than 50 km/s.
After going around a few times within the virtual radius of the host galaxy, they evolve into systems with greater mass and higher surface brightness.
Our results indicate that TDs may be responsible for the light in certain parts of the diffuse star clusters observed around the nearby rich star clusters.
Tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs) are small star-forming objects that exist within interacting or merging galaxies.
Their origin is still a matter of controversy, but some suggest that they were formed due to tidal interference when gas-rich satellites approached the center of their parent galaxy.
For this work, we used high-resolution hydrodynamic cosmological zoom simulations to study the formation and evolution of TDGs, which were performed using the RAMSES-RT code.
We indicate that tidal disruption gaps (TDGs) can be generated by the destruction occurring at the first pericenter passage through the gas-rich satellites in the main galaxy halo.
The quality of these TDGs is typically between \(10^8 M_{\odot}\) and \(10^{11} M_{\odot}\), with sizes less than 100 parsecs and circumferential velocities exceeding 50 kilometers per second.
After multiple orbital cycles, these tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs) grow in mass and volume, becoming brighter and bluer.
Finally, our research findings indicate that TDGs may account for 50% of the total scattered interstellar light observed around nearby rich galaxy clusters.

We found that our MGFLD model can reproduce many of the features observed in recent two-dimensional hydrodynamic simulations, including the growth rate of SASI and its characteristic spiral pattern structure.

These tests indicate that both parts contribute significantly to the overall dynamics of the system, but the convective part undoubtedly plays a dominant role.

Mutations in proteins can lead to diseases such as cancer and cystic fibrosis.
In this study, we propose a new method that predicts the effect of single-point mutations on protein thermodynamic stability (ΔG) using only sequence information.
The proposed method is based on an ensemble learning technique called Random Forest, which combines multiple decision trees into one model.
We demonstrate how our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods by achieving greater accuracy with lower computational cost.
Our results indicate that the proposed method can be used to predict the ΔG values of thousands of mutants in a single evaluation.
Mutations in proteins are known to lead to many human diseases, including cancer and cystic fibrosis.
Therefore, it is important to understand the impact of these mutations on the structure and function of proteins.
One method to study the effects of mutations is through their influence on protein thermodynamic stability.
Thermodynamic stability refers to the free energy difference between the folded state and the unfolded state.
A negative value indicates that the interaction in the folded state is more favorable than in the unfolded state, while a positive value indicates that the interaction is unfavorable.
The change in Gibbs free energy (ΔGf) during the folding process shows a good correlation with experimental measurement results, which has been demonstrated in the research.
Therefore, the accurate prediction of ΔGf will help us better understand the relationship between mutations and diseases.
We present the results of our investigation into the physical properties of polar broad absorption line quasars (BALQSOs).
We found that BAL QSOs are more likely to be radio-strong compared to non-BAL QSOs, and they have higher brightness at ultraviolet wavelengths in a static frame.
The proportion of BALQSOs in our sample is consistent with previous studies; however, we did not find a significant difference in the proportion of BALQSOs between radio-quiet and radio-loud quasars.
Furthermore, we found no evidence indicating that there are differences in the properties of broad absorption lines (BALs) observed along different sightlines within a single celestial object.
In conclusion, we demonstrate a correlation between the strength of the CIV emission line blue shift and the equivalent width of the associated BAL troughs.
These findings suggest that BALQSO may represent a special class of radio-loud quasars, characterized by a high accretion rate onto supermassive black holes.

We present a phase space atlas for describing the possible motions of a class of conservative Lagrangian mechanical systems in two dimensions, characterized by having one first-order and one second-order integral of motion.

We demonstrate how this method allows us to obtain explicit expressions for general solutions to certain specific problems, such as those related to the harmonic oscillator or the Kepler problem.

We studied the simple shear flow of two different types of inelastic Maxwell models, one with a constant recovery coefficient and the other with a velocity-dependent recovery coefficient.
We found that when the system only has elastic collisions, there is no steady-state solution; however, if we add some dissipative effects, a steady-state solution does exist.
The steady-state solution is found to be independent of the initial conditions and the types of dissipation included.
In addition, we also indicate that these equilibrium states are linearly stable under small perturbations.
Finally, we present the results related to the relaxation time scales associated with the problem, which can be used to estimate the rate at which the system approaches a steady state.
Introduction: Simple shear flow has been extensively studied both theoretically [1]-[3] and experimentally [4]-[6].
The motivation for these studies lies in the fact that such flows naturally occur in many physical systems, such as granular materials and colloidal suspensions.

Recent research shows that, despite the potential complexity of microscopic dynamics (such as in the case of granular materials), the macroscopic behavior of the system can still be described by relatively simple kinetic theory equations, such as the Boltzmann equation or the Enskog equation.
However, most of these works focus on the elastic interactions between particles, while typically neglecting the impact of dissipation.
This assumption is not always valid, especially in cases where particles interact through soft potential interactions.

We study the ground state properties of two-flavor color superconducting (2SC) quark matter at finite density and temperature, using an effective axial model with vector interactions derived from quantum chromodynamics (QCD) in the mean field approximation.

This new phase is referred to as the Larkin-Ovchinnikova-Fulde-Ferrell (LOFF) state, as it was originally proposed to describe superfluidity in nuclear systems.

We provide a higher algebraic K-theory using explicit descriptions of certain universal homotopy classes, which are defined using only the ring structure and unit element of the underlying commutative ring.

In this work, we propose an efficient direct voting scheme to provide data fusion assurance (DFA) in wireless sensor networks (WSNs).

The proposed DFA scheme is based on the concept that each node can directly cast a local vote based on the decisions of other nodes, and then arrive at a final global decision through a majority voting rule.

To reduce the communication overhead generated during the direct voting process, our scheme employs two novel techniques: 1) allowing only one-hop neighbors to vote at any given moment; 2) having all nodes transmit their votes simultaneously using different time slots.
We also provide theoretical analysis to demonstrate how much energy consumption will be saved compared to existing solutions.
Finally, extensive simulation results show that our scheme outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in both accuracy and power efficiency.
Keywords: Data fusion guarantee, wireless sensor networks, energy-saving direct voting scheme.

1 Introduction

Broad Absorption Line Quasars (BALQSOs) exhibit blueshifted absorption features in their emission spectra. They account for only 10%-20% of optically selected quasar samples, but may contribute up to 50% of the total ultraviolet continuum flux absorbed by intervening gas clouds that are located away from the line of sight of the quasars (Weymann et al., 1991).

In addition to serving as an important probe for studying the internal physical conditions of gas absorption, broad absorption line quasars (BALQSOs) also provide information on the characteristics of the surrounding interstellar medium through the study of related metal line systems (for example, Weymann et al., 1979; Foltz et al., 1986; Turnshek & Savage 1988; Hamann 1998a, b, 1999).

However, apart from their importance as cosmological tools, there has been little significant progress in understanding these objects since their first discovery over 30 years ago, mainly due to the inherent selection effects in optical surveys (see, for example, Hewett & Foltz 2003).

Recently, several authors have suggested that many BALQSOs (broad absorption line quasars) can be discovered among infrared-selected sources by utilizing large near-infrared sky surveys, such as the Two Micron All Sky Survey (2MASS).

We are releasing a document for the first time, containing all the X-ray Telescope (XRT) data of gamma-ray bursts observed since the launch of the Swift satellite in November 2004.
XRT is sensitive to soft X-ray photons with energies ranging from 0.3 to 10 keV, with a field of view of 23 x 23 arcminutes.

It has two operating modes: window timing mode, which provides high time resolution but low sensitivity; and photon counting mode, which offers higher sensitivity at the expense of timing information.
We have processed all publicly released XRT data into a unified database using standard procedures.
This includes the calibration observations conducted before the launch as well as the in-orbit calibration performed after each observation.
After each outbreak, we provide a table that outlines the basic attributes of the event and the original count rate measured throughout the exposure period.

We also detected significant hard X-ray emissions above 10 keV, which cannot be solely explained by thermal bremsstrahlung radiation.
One possible explanation is that soft photons undergo inverse Compton scattering with electrons accelerated to relativistic speeds in the shock wave.
If this is the case, then these particles should be accelerated to energies exceeding 1 PeV.

We use this equation to directly obtain the components of the metric tensor from the observed trajectories of photons emitted at different redshifts.
This method allows us to reconstruct the complete four-dimensional geometry in spacetime without assuming any specific model or parameterization.

It also aims to promote international cooperation among researchers engaged in work related to Einstein across different fields.

We propose a method for calculating probability amplitudes in quantum walk models that is different from the usual Feynman path integral description. This method is based on the concept of scattering states and their associated S-matrix elements.
We demonstrate that this new formalism enables us to obtain precise results for several interesting cases where standard methods fail or are inapplicable.
Specifically, we consider two different types of boundary conditions at one end of the chain (the origin), which leads to completely different behaviors of the system during its time evolution.

The first type is referred to as Dirichlet boundary conditions, which means that particles are reflected back to the origin after leaving it; while the second case refers to particles being absorbed when they reach the origin.
For these two cases, we precisely calculate the evolution operator for all \( t > 0 \) using our new method.

Finally, by applying the inverse Fourier transform to the evolutionary operator, we can recover the full probability distribution function of the walker being at any position x on the chain at time t.
We present new observational results for the symbiotic binary system H1-36, including optical, infrared (IR), and ultraviolet (UV) spectral ranges.
The analysis is based on high-resolution spectral data obtained using the UVES spectrograph on the VLT telescope, as well as low-resolution data provided by other authors.
We found that the observed spectrum can be explained by two components: one is the accretion disk around the white dwarf, and the other is the red giant.
Through addition, we detected emission lines originating from the winds of red giant stars.
Our results are consistent with previous studies, which indicate that the celestial body belongs to a symbiotic system, where mass transfer occurs via Roche lobe overflow.
Keywords: symbiotic relationship, binary star system, red giant, accreting binary star, wind, mass loss, spectroscopy, ultraviolet radiation, white dwarf, emission lines, stellar wind.

We propose an improved factorization formula for the fragmentation functions (FFs) that is applicable to hadrons containing a heavy quark, and is valid in both the leading order and next-to-leading order of QCD perturbation theory.
The new formula takes into account all possible contributions of the force fields (FFs) at each order of perturbation.
We indicate that our results are consistent with those obtained using other methods, such as operator product expansion or renormalization group equation methods.
Finally, we provided numerical predictions for some important quantities related to the flavor quark distribution functions (FFs).

We have proposed an exact expression for the energy density functional, which is based on local electronic charge and spin density as variables. It is applicable to any number N of electrons on the surface of two-dimensional soft matter under arbitrary strengths of spin-orbit interactions.
The result and rules derived by Stinger and Lovett (SL) under the condition of zero spin-orbit coupling are equivalent, but they also include additional contributions arising from this term.
We indicate that these new items can only be represented as functions of the SL parameters.
This result allows us to obtain explicit expressions for all relevant physical quantities, such as the exchange-correlation potential or magnetization profile at finite temperatures.
Finally, we discussed how our results could be used to improve existing approximate methods in density functional theory.

We reported the first demonstration of high bit-rate and low error rate quantum key distribution (QKD) over a fiber optic link spanning more than 100 kilometers, which includes 20 kilometers of standard telecom fiber and 80 kilometers of dispersion-shifted fiber.
The quantum key distribution system uses polarization encoding and the decoy-state BB84 protocol to generate a secret key for each user at a maximum rate of up to 1 Mbit/s.
We use two types of single-photon detectors, which are based on InGaAs/InP avalanche photodiodes, operating in either Geiger mode or gated mode single-photon counting.
In order to overcome the dark count noise of the detector, we adopted an active feedforward technique, which enables us to achieve a secure key generation rate of 0.5 Mbit/s for each user.
This is the highest secure key generation rate reported so far in quantum key distribution systems with transmission distances exceeding 50 kilometers.

Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) allows two remote users to share a secret key by exchanging quantum states over an insecure channel. Due to its potential applications in military and commercial fields, it has attracted significant attention in recent years.

We use numerical simulations that incorporate N-body particles and fluid dynamics to study the nonlinear evolution of baryon acoustic oscillations (BAO) in an expanding universe.
We found that baryon acoustic oscillations (BAOs) are suppressed by nonlinear gravitational clustering, but they can be restored by applying a Wiener filter to the density field at each redshift.
The reconstructed power spectrum is very consistent with the predictions of linear theory on large scales, where the effects are negligible.
However, at a small scale, we observe significant deviations between the two spectra due to nonlinear effects such as shell crossing and potential energy effects.
These results suggest that BAOs may still be used as standard rulers for cosmic distance measurements, even in cases where the underlying matter distribution is highly nonlinear.

1. Introduction: Quark matter plays an important role in the formation of galaxies through its interactions with dark matter.
For example, observations show that galaxies form around the peaks of primordial density fluctuations, which grow into massive halos through gravitational instability.
Therefore, understanding the evolution of baryons in time and space is crucial for studying the process of galaxy formation.
In recent years, there has been a growing interest in using baryonic tracers such as neutral hydrogen or stars to measure the large-scale structure of the universe.
A promising approach involves using spectral surveys to trace the spatial distribution of these objects.
This technology enables us to measure the statistical properties of the cosmic web over a wide range of redshifts, including its geometric shape and topological structure.
The most significant feature observed in the correlation functions measured by various types of baryon detectors is referred to as "Baryon Acoustic Oscillations" (BAO).
It refers to the periodic fluctuations observed in the power spectrum of a tracer particle population before the sound waves propagated through decoupling in the early universe [see, for example, 1].

Due to the fact that the amplitude of the BAO signal is only weakly correlated with the physical state of the medium, it provides a robust method for probing the history of cosmic expansion independently of other cosmological parameters [2].
Recently, several research groups reported the detection of BAO features in the correlation function related to Lyman.
We reported four new quasars with a redshift of z > 6, discovered in the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS).
These objects are selected as part of a continuous survey of high-redshift quasars, using optical data obtained from CFHT and the Spitzer Space Telescope.
We have shown their optical to near-infrared spectral energy distributions (SED), which can be well fitted using composite quasar templates.
Their luminosity ranges from \(1.5 \times 10^{14} \, \text{erg} \, \text{s}^{-1} \, \text{cm}^{-2}\) to \(2.1 \times 10^{15} \, \text{erg} \, \text{s}^{-1} \, \text{cm}^{-2}\).
These results indicate that there is still potential to discover very bright quasars at redshift six and above.
They also provide further evidence that supermassive black holes grew rapidly during the early stages of galaxy formation.

The Large Area Telescope (LAT) is one of the two instruments on the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope, which was launched by NASA in June 2008.
The LAT consists of a series of silicon-strip detectors and cesium iodide calorimeters, capable of detecting gamma rays with energies ranging from 20 MeV to over 300 GeV.

We introduced the concept of Generalized Conditional Random Fields (GCRFs) and demonstrated how they can be used to model arbitrary probability distributions on structured datasets such as sequences or trees.
We propose an efficient algorithm to learn the GCRF parameters by performing gradient descent on the log-likelihood objective function.

In the end, we proved that our method can learn accurate models for multiple challenging sequence labeling tasks, including part-of-speech tagging in natural language processing and protein secondary structure prediction in bioinformatics.

Conditional Random Fields (CRFs) (Lafferty et al., 2001) are undirected graphical models that have been successfully applied to many problems involving sequential data, such as those described by Sha and Pereira (2003).

Based on this work, we propose Generalized Conditional Random Fields (GCRFs), which are an extension of Conditional Random Fields (CRFs) that allow us to represent distributions over arbitrary structured datasets (such as sequences or trees).
The key idea behind GCRFs is to use a set of latent variables to capture the dependencies between different parts of the input space.
This enables us to efficiently compute the necessary induction functions for standard conditional random fields using dynamic programming techniques.
Additionally, this also makes it possible to use gradient-based methods, similar to those employed in maximum entropy Markov models (MEMMs), to train GCRFs.
To evaluate the performance of our method, we applied it to two important application scenarios: part-of-speech tagging.

The study investigated the effects of three different sugars (trehalose, maltose, and sucrose) on the structure and dynamics of lysozyme, using molecular dynamics simulations at 300 K for a duration of 100 nanoseconds for each case.

The results indicate that all of these sugar molecules are able to stabilize proteins to some extent and prevent their thermal denaturation, but it was found that trehalose is the most effective among them.
Maltose molecules form hydrogen bonds with polar and non-polar amino acid residues, thereby increasing the number of surrounding water molecules.
This increases the thickness of the protein hydration shell and the total solvent-accessible surface area.
It also reduces the root mean square deviation between the initial structure and the final structure, indicating its ability to maintain the native conformation of the protein.
Maltose and sucrose form fewer hydrogen bonds with proteins, so their efficiency is lower than that of trehalose.
In addition, their presence leads to a slight decrease in the radius of gyration and the end-to-end distance of the protein.

We study spin-1/2 fermions on an infinite square lattice with nearest-neighbor hopping and pairing interactions, using exact diagonalization techniques to calculate their ground state energy and momentum distribution function at zero temperature.

We find that for weak coupling (small values of t/J), the system is in a superfluid phase, characterized by non-diagonal long-range order; however, when t/J exceeds a critical value tc(μ) that depends on the chemical potential μ, this state becomes unstable.
For strong coupling (large values of t/J), we indicate the presence of another stable phase in which the system exhibits no long-range off-diagonal order, but still shows gapless excitations.
This new phase can be viewed as a pairing state similar to BCS, but without any symmetry breaking.
The transition between these two phases occurs through a quantum phase transition.
Finally, we discuss the possible experimental realizations of the Hamiltonian of our model.

Finally, I will discuss some possibilities for future experiments to test some key predictions proposed in the standard model.

The proposed method adopts a population-based approach, where each individual represents a valid solution through a permutation vector.

We analyzed the synthetic star catalog used for calibrating photometric measurements surveys (such as Gaia and LSST).
We demonstrate that these libraries are not accurate enough for this purpose, as their models do not include all relevant physical processes (e.g., convection).
This can lead to some systemic errors when using them for photometric calibration or deriving distances.

We demonstrated how to use observational data from open star clusters with known ages and metal abundances to test the accuracy of different synthesis libraries by comparing the observed properties of the clusters with the predicted properties.
Finally, we discussed possible improvements to the current synthetic library.
The next generation of space telescopes may provide unprecedented data about our galaxy.
These new datasets require a lot of effort to achieve correct analysis.

An important aspect is the calibration of photometric surveys, such as Gaia and LSST, which can provide precise astronomical measurements and multi-color photometric data for billions of stars in the sky.
In order to obtain high-precision results, it is crucial to understand the potential sources of errors and biases that may be introduced during the data processing process.
In particular, it is essential to ensure that the resulting absolute magnitude M_(V) is accurate to 0.01 magnitudes across most of the color range covered by the survey.

For example, if the distance modulus DM = 5log10(d/d_sun), where d is the actual distance between us and the star, and d_sun is the distance from the Sun to the Earth, then a difference of 0.01 magnitudes corresponds to a distance that is 1.1 times greater.
Therefore, even small uncertainties in the absolute magnitude scale can translate into significant errors in the inferred distances.
Therefore, it is crucial to accurately determine a reliable method for measuring the absolute magnitude of individual stars before deriving distances.
Currently, there are several methods based on theoretical models of the atmosphere to estimate absolute magnitude.
However, these models often cannot meet observational constraints under low temperature and/or high surface gravity conditions.
Therefore, the obtained absolute magnitude may deviate significantly from the magnitude obtained through other techniques (such as eclipsing binaries).
Moreover, some of these models also have issues with incompleteness.

1. Introduction.
The discovery of extremely low-mass stars has opened up new avenues for understanding how planets form around very cold dwarf stars.
However, there are still many uncertainties regarding the formation process of this system and its chemical composition.
An important aspect of this issue involves determining whether the formation of terrestrial planets can occur within the habitable zone of ultra-cool dwarf stars.

To answer this question, it is necessary to determine whether there are large amounts of heavy elements in the atmosphere of these stars, such as carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, sulfur, sodium, potassium, magnesium, aluminum, silicon, calcium, titanium, iron, nickel, cobalt, copper, zinc, arsenic, selenium, silver, gold, mercury, lead, uranium, thorium, and actinium.

It should be noted that while some of these metals are produced during the nucleosynthesis in stars, other metals are synthesized solely through cosmic ray spallation reactions that occur outside of stars.
We presented a study on the orbital stability of the 14 planetary systems discovered by HATNet and the Kepler Space Telescope around the star HD 10180 (HIP 108427).
We use numerical integration to demonstrate that the system is dynamically stable on timescales exceeding its age, and we estimate its age to be 4 billion years through rotational chronology.
The planets are distributed in two resonant chains, with their period ratios close to 2:1 and 3:2.
The chains are connected through the average motion resonance between adjacent pairs of planets.
This structure indicates that the system is sculpted within the envelope of each planet through convergent migration and subsequent tidal dissipation.

Keywords: Planetary systems - stability - mean motion resonance - convergent migration - tides - spin chronology - HD10180 - Kepler telescope - HATNet telescope - orbital dynamics - dynamical evolution

We study how the influence of galactic winds can be used to explain the characteristics of the metal-poor tails observed in the stellar metallicity distributions (SMDs) of nearby dwarf spheroidal galaxies (dSph).
We found that SMD is very sensitive to the rate of quality loss and wind speed, but it is not very sensitive to other parameters, such as the initial mass function or star formation history.
The best-fit model for each galaxy is obtained by comparing its interstellar medium density (SMD) with the SMD predicted using different sets of free parameters.
Our results indicate that these dwarf elliptical galaxies underwent strong outflows driven by supernova explosions during their early evolutionary stages.
These outflows are responsible for removing most of the metals produced by stars that formed before z = 1.5-2.0.
In addition, we also found that some of them may experience additional late-stage outflow events, which could remove more metals generated after this time period.
We present new spectral observations of over 1,000 Galactic OB supergiants obtained using FLAMES/GIRAFFE on the Very Large Telescope (VLT).
The sample includes all known O-type dwarfs and giants, as well as B-type supergiants that are brighter than approximately Mbol.
The astronomical magnitude within 25 parsecs (pc) from Earth is -4.
We derive the atmospheric parameters T_eff, logarithmic gravity log g, microturbulence velocity vmic, and the chemical composition, including nitrogen abundance [N/Fe].
For comparison, we also used a similar method to analyze a large number of red supergiants in the Milky Way observed by the GOSSS project.
Our results indicate that there is no significant difference in the means of these quantities obtained from the two samples.
However, our analysis shows that there are systematic differences between various studies based on smaller samples up to now.

Specifically, we found that most previous studies have overestimated the temperatures of hotter bodies due to neglecting non-local thermodynamic equilibrium (non-LTE) effects or underestimating gravities, as they did not take stellar winds into account.
We present near-infrared (NIR) imaging and spectroscopy of star formation activity in the Bok nebula CB 54, located about 1 kpc in the direction of the Galactic anti-center.

We found two young stellar objects (YSOs): one is a Class I protostar with an infrared brightness about 10 times that of the Sun, and the other is an embedded YSO candidate with an overall temperature of about 1000 K.
The former object shows a bipolar outflow traced by the Herbig-Haro knots and molecular outflow wings.
In addition to these two sources, we have also detected several other point-like near-infrared sources in the central region of CB 54.
These may be low-quality pre-main-sequence stars or background galaxies.
Our results indicate that this cloud core has undergone active star formation during its lifetime.
Keywords: star formation; near-infrared spectroscopy; bipolar outflows; young stellar objects.
We propose a method for handling non-equilibrium entropy production in the lattice Boltzmann (LB) method by introducing an entropy limiter in the collision operator.

The proposed scheme has been shown to reproduce the correct balanced distribution and restore the second law of thermodynamics, applicable to single-phase flows with constant density and temperature as well as to multiphase flows with phase changes.
We also demonstrated that our new LB model can accurately capture shock waves without producing spurious oscillations or numerical instabilities.
Keywords: non-equilibrium entropy, lattice Boltzmann method, entropy limiter, second law of thermodynamics, shock wave.

We consider the search for an approximate solution to a convex optimization problem, which has a non-convex objective function and linear constraints, with the feasible region defined by a set of equality or inequality constraints.

We indicate that under certain conditions, this problem can be efficiently solved by combining gradient descent methods (used to solve subproblems at each iteration) and line search methods based on the Armijo-Goldstein condition.

We present our search results for high-redshift galaxies through narrowband imaging in the near-infrared (NIR) and optical bands, as well as spectral follow-up observations at the Keck Observatory.
We identified two new candidates for galaxies with redshifts greater than 6 by searching for strong emission lines, such as Lyman-alpha or CIV, in their rest-frame ultraviolet spectra.
The first candidate is an extremely bright celestial body, detected at z=6.96 through both photometric and spectroscopic measurements.
The source shows no evidence of Active Galactic Nucleus (AGN) activity, but it does show signs of star formation.

The second candidate was discovered accidentally during our investigation of another target; based on its near-infrared color and being undetected in the B-band filter, it also appears to be located at z=6-7.
These two sources are among the most distant galaxies known.
These celestial bodies will provide important constraints for reionization models, as they can be used to study how ionizing photons escape into the interstellar medium.
We present the regularized versions of two popular general relativity evolution codes, namely, the code based on the BSSN formulation and the code using the moving puncture method.
The new scheme is aimed at being used with any measurement condition that can be formulated as a first-order differential equation.
We demonstrated how to implement these schemes into existing code by adding just one additional equation at each time step.
Through addition, we provide an explicit expression for the source term that appears in this additional equation, which is valid under all the norms considered here.
Finally, we numerically demonstrate the performance of our scheme by evolving multiple test problems, including black hole spacetimes with apparent horizons.
Our results indicate that the new scheme performs well even when evolving over multiple dynamic time scales.

We analyzed the relativistic Riemann problem for two-dimensional ideal fluids, with particular emphasis on the role of vortex sheets.

We demonstrate that the solution to this problem can be constructed as a series of self-similar solutions, which are uniquely determined under translations along the x-axis (the direction of propagation).
The first step is to construct a family of exact solutions to describe the interaction between plane shock waves and vortex sheets.
The solutions were previously obtained using different methods, but we provide a new derivation here based on a characteristic method.
In particular, we obtained explicit expressions for the density and pressure distributions ahead of the shock.
Next, we consider the case where the initial data is composed of a single vortex surface that separates regions of constant density and constant pressure.
This situation physically corresponds to a fluid that is initially at rest being瞬间 accelerated by a piston at speed c = 1.
We prove that for every total mass M, there exists exactly one such solution.
Finally, we study the evolution of more general initial data consisting of several vortex sheets separated by shock waves using numerical methods.

Our main findings are as follows: The abundance ratios between different species show that the abundance of H2O is several orders of magnitude higher than that of any other molecule.
The derived column density indicates significant differences in the physical conditions of the observed region.
The chemical composition of the gas shows significant differences between the two sources.
Our comparison with previous research data indicates that there may be multiple evolutionary stages for each source.

Specifically, we consider a particular case where a certain characteristic speed vanishes at one point but remains away from zero elsewhere.

The electrostatic interaction between two asymmetric charged membranes was studied using mean field theory and Monte Carlo simulations.

We propose that the metal enhancement observed in certain post-T Tauri stars (PTTS) may be due to the accumulation of planetesimals during their formation stage, followed by the rapid formation of planets that are then ejected into space.

We indicate that this scenario can explain the high metal abundance found in PTTSs, as well as the low abundance ratios of refractory elements, such as Mg/Si or Al/Si, compared to what would be expected if these bodies formed through the standard core-accretion process.

We present the results of an analysis of the shapes, orientations, and alignments of dark matter subhalos in cosmological N-body simulations, which include different levels of baryonic physics.

We found that the inclusion of baryons has a small impact on the shape distribution but a significant effect on the spin parameter distribution; when baryons are included, the halo is more spherical compared to when it is only affected by gravity.
All considered models (including pure dark matter) tend to align their halo rotation perpendicular to their major axis.
This is consistent with previous studies, which found similar trends using other methods.

1 Introduction

In recent years, several new classes of transient celestial objects have been discovered through systematic searches using satellites such as RXTE/ASM or Swift/BAT.

These include soft gamma repeaters (SGRs; for example, Hurley et al., 2005), anomalous X-ray pulsars (AXPs; for example, Kaspi and Beloborodov, 2017), and magnetar candidates (for example, Rea et al., 2012).
Among them, SGR exhibits repeated short bursts of high-energy radiation, with a frequency range from radio waves to gamma rays.
The characteristic of AXP is the continuous emission of X-rays, which typically exhibit periodic pulsations.
The candidates for magnetars also exhibit characteristics similar to AXP, but lack obvious evidence of periodicity.
All three types of sources occasionally emit massive flares accompanied by the phenomenon of energetic particle acceleration (for example, Palmer 2014; Kashiyama et al., 2013).
On the other hand, these celestial bodies sometimes experience weak outbursts that last from several hours to several days.

For example, SGR 0526-66 exhibited a series of such outburst phenomena in 1979 and 1989 (Mazets et al., 1981; Cline et al., 1982; Kulkarni et al., 1993; Kouveliotou et al., 1998), while SGR 1900+14 showed another series of weaker bursts between 1997 and 2001.

We analyzed the galaxy morphology, brightness, and environment in the Abel 901;902 supercluster (redshift z = 0.18), using data from the Wide Field Imager on the Very Large Telescope at the European Southern Observatory.
We found that the proportion of early-type galaxies significantly increases in regions with higher local density within this supercluster.
Morphological mixing has also been found to significantly depend on absolute magnitude; at fixed density, dimmer galaxies are more likely to be late-type galaxies compared to brighter galaxies.
These results indicate that both environmental effects and internal processes play important roles in shaping the observed morphology-density relationship.

We study the effect of geometry on the transmission characteristics of one-dimensional (1D) and two-dimensional (2D) systems with periodic boundary conditions through precise mapping to random walks.

We indicate that there is no difference between open boundary conditions and periodic boundary conditions for one-dimensional chains; however, this statement no longer holds when considering two-dimensional lattices.
Specifically, we found that the self-diffusion coefficient D(t), which describes how quickly particles diffuse through space at time t, has a strong dependence on the lattice structure.

For example, if the system consists of two identical sublattices that are connected only through transition processes along the bonds connecting them, then the variation of D(t) with time exhibits non-monotonic behavior: it first increases until it reaches a maximum value after some characteristic relaxation time, and then decreases towards zero.
This behavior can be explained by analyzing the probability distribution P(r,t) of finding a particle at position r at time t.

We have measured the mass function of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) for the first time, covering both early-type (elliptical/S0, Sa-Sb) and late-type (Scd-Sm) galaxies, using data from the Millennium Galaxy Catalogue (MGC).
We use two different methods to measure the mass of supermassive black holes—stellar velocity dispersion measurements and the bulge luminosity relation.
Our results show that there is no significant difference between the mass functions of supermassive black holes (SMBH) of these galaxy types when z < 0.1.
However, we found evidence that as the redshift increases, the number density of supermassive black holes decreases more rapidly than that of smaller black holes.
This suggests that the largest supermassive black holes (SMBHs) may have grown through accretion over cosmic time rather than through merger events.
These findings may impose important constraints on the growth of supermassive black holes and the feedback models of active galactic nuclei.

Both groups are related to an extended bipolar structure observed in previous single-dish observations.
This structure is interpreted as a shell-like outer envelope surrounding the central star.
Our results indicate that the two groups of emitters tracked different parts of this shell-like structure.
In addition, we found evidence indicating the existence of a third component, which may be related to the presence of a companion star.

Muon-catalyzed fusion (MCF) is a special type of nuclear reaction that can be used to generate energy in future reactors, but it requires extremely pure hydrogen gas as fuel.

The MuCap experiment at TRIUMF developed and tested a novel system for producing ultra-pure hydrogen gas through low-temperature distillation with liquid helium and subsequent two-stage molecular sieve technology.
The system can produce up to 1 liter of water per minute, with impurity levels lower than one trillionth.
It will provide sufficient clean hydrogen to support the operation of the MuCap experiment until 2020, at which time the next generation of experiments is expected to begin collecting data.
A循环氢超高纯化系统 was designed and constructed for the MuCap experiment of TRI-UMF.
Liquid helium low-temperature distillation is combined with two levels of molecular sieve beds to achieve the high purity levels required for MCF research.
The system provides up to one liter of purified hydrogen per minute, with impurity content of less than ten trillionths.

GRI (Gamma-ray Imaging Observatory) is an astrophysical space observatory proposed by the French National Centre for Space Studies (CNES) and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), aimed at studying gamma-ray bursts, active galactic nuclei, and other high-energy astronomical phenomena.
It will be launched by an alliance rocket equipped with a Flagot senior, entering the Sun-Earth L2 orbit at a distance of 1 astronomical unit from Earth.

Its main instruments consist of two coded mask telescopes that can observe simultaneously in the energy range from 20 MeV to 300 GeV. Each telescope has a large field of view of 2 steradians and a spatial resolution better than 0.1 degrees.
The third detector module provides additional information about the background radiation environment for each telescope.
This article describes the design concept of this innovative instrument.
Keywords: cosmic particle physics, high-energy astronomy, instruments, space observatory.

We used the exact diagonalization method to investigate the magnetization process, thermodynamic properties, and magnetization rate of a spin-1/2 diamond chain with nearest-neighbor interactions in an external magnetic field.
We found that there is no spontaneous magnetization at zero temperature, but when the system is heated to certain critical temperatures, the system exhibits finite magnetization.
The results show that the ground state has antiferromagnetic order, while the excited state has ferromagnetic order.

In addition, we also studied the effect of the external magnetic field on the magnetization process by calculating the magnetization curves M(H) at different temperatures T = 0.1J, 1.0J, 2.0J, 3.0J, and 4.0J (where J is the exchange interaction).
The results indicate that as H increases, the magnetization intensity rapidly increases until it reaches the saturation value Msat at high fields.
In addition, our numerical calculations show that the Curie-Weiss constant decreases gradually with the increase of J and eventually disappears at larger values of J.
The subgrid-scale stress tensor is an important quantity in Large Eddy Simulation (LES), which describes the effect of unresolved turbulent motions on the resolved scales.
In this work, we propose a new closure scheme based on the matrix exponential function to model the anisotropic part of the subgrid-scale stress tensor and its associated transport coefficients.
The proposed closure model is derived by assuming statistical homogeneity and isotropy for each computational unit at small length scales.
We show that these closures can be represented by simple algebraic expressions that only involve second-order statistics of the velocity field.
The closed equations were tested through direct numerical simulations of uniform shear flow with different Reynolds numbers, ranging from Re = 100 to 1000.
The research findings indicate that our proposed closure model performs better in terms of normalized mean square error comparison than the existing vortex viscosity-based closure models.
Finally, it should be noted that the proposed closure scheme has been implemented in the open-source LES code Nektar++.

The vibration infrared lifetime (VIL) of N2O dissolved in water was measured using an optical parametric oscillator pumped by a 1064 nm Nd3+-doped YAG laser, with the emission signal detected at 1270 nm, corresponding to the ground state vibration mode of N2O. The VIL value of pure water is 1.6 ± 0.1 microseconds.
This result is in good agreement with the previously reported results.
For solutions containing different concentrations of NaCl or KCl, it was found that the VIL value is independent of salt concentration within the experimental error range.
These results indicate that the vibrational relaxation process of N2O molecules in aqueous solution does not involve any specific interactions between N2O and Cl- ions.

It should also be noted that the current measurements were conducted under conditions where the interactions between solute and solvent can be considered negligible compared to the interactions observed in concentrated solutions.
Therefore, it can be concluded that the vibrational relaxation mechanism of N2O in dilute solution is essentially the same as that in pure water.
We propose a model that describes the process of spontaneous formation within a collection of neurons, based on an unsupervised Hebbian learning rule with synaptic inhibition.

The network is composed of N interconnected neurons, which are connected to each other through excitatory connections. The strength of these connections varies according to their firing rates, based on an inhibitory function.
We demonstrate how this mechanism leads to the emergence of stable states characterized by different average activity levels and the number of synchronized clusters.

We particularly discovered that there is a critical threshold for connection probability; once this value is exceeded, the system undergoes a phase transition and enters a state where all neurons discharge synchronously at high frequency.
This state corresponds to the observed episodes of epilepsy in the experiment.
In addition, we study the impact of external stimuli on the dynamics of our network.
By applying brief electrical pulses to specific groups of neurons, we can trigger transitions between different dynamic states.
Finally, we discuss the potential applications of these results in neurobiology.
We present new Chandra observations of the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) in Abel 3395 (z=0.084).
There is an extended halo around the BCG, with a temperature range between 1 keV and 5 keV.
We found that this hot gas has shifted from its original position (around the central galaxy) due to interactions with other galaxies in the core of the star cluster.
Through addition, we detected two radio sources associated with BCG, which are likely to be jets or halos of active galactic nuclei (AGN).
In the end, we identified several regions where cold gas may have condensed from the surrounding hot plasma.
These results indicate that the BCG in Abel 3395 is significantly interacting with its environment.

The purpose of this lecture is to present some of the latest results regarding the relationship between integrability in quantum field theory, statistical mechanics, or mathematical physics, and the special geometric structures (complex algebraic curves) associated with these models.
We will discuss how to use techniques from algebraic geometry, such as Riemann surfaces, theta functions, etc., to accurately solve certain physical problems.
We will also explain why many interesting integrable models seem to have the fundamental structure of Riemann surfaces.
Finally, we will provide examples to illustrate that this connection has been clearly pointed out.
This presentation will include several recent new findings obtained by the author and his collaborators.
This work was partially supported by the German Research Foundation (DFG), funding number SFB/TR9.
Integrable systems play an important role in various branches of mathematics and theoretical physics.
They naturally arise, especially when studying solvable lattice models in statistical mechanics or quantum field theory.
It has been proven that there is a profound relationship between integrality and a special geometric structure called an algebraic curve.
These curves provide powerful tools for precisely solving certain physical problems using methods of algebraic geometry (such as Riemann surfaces and theta functions).
