Supersymmetry is one of the most promising extensions beyond the Standard Model, and it involves many unresolved issues, such as the hierarchy problem between the electroweak scale and the Planck scale, as well as the unification of forces.
In addition, it provides a natural candidate for cold dark matter – the lightest neutralino.
The Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (MSSM) has been widely studied over the past two decades, but it has several drawbacks.
One of the reasons is that the Standard Model does not explain why there are three generations of quarks and leptons with different quantum numbers.

The Grand Unified Theories (GUTs) address this issue by hypothesizing that all known particles, including the third generation particles, belong to various representations of a larger symmetry group than SU(3)xSU(2)xU(1).
This naturally leads to the relationship between the coupling constants and the fermion mass matrix.
Another disadvantage of the MSSM is that it cannot explain the experimentally observed small neutrino masses.
However, if R symmetry is broken, then the Majorana neutrino may acquire a tiny mass through the seesaw mechanism.
These new states can also significantly contribute to the relic density of dark matter.
We present an overview of the theory of vortices in dilute atomic gases trapped at low temperatures.

We discussed how these systems are described by a macroscopic wave function and indicated that they are governed by a nonlinear Schrödinger equation under the influence of an external potential field.
The solution to this equation has been widely discussed after years of research. We will review some properties related to vortex formation.

Specifically, we consider the stationary states corresponding to non-rotating condensate configurations (without vortices) and those rotation states that carry quantized angular momentum due to phase singularities known as vortices.
Finally, we briefly describe the recent experiments on the generation of vortices in cold atomic clouds.

They have quantized angular momentum and play an important role in various physical phenomena, including turbulence and quantum transport processes.
Here we provide an introduction to the theoretical description of vortices in trapped atomic gases.
We proposed an algorithm for solving the Graph Isomorphism Problem (GIP) based on quantum walks and Grover's search algorithm.
The proposed method is inspired by classic algorithms that use random walks, but it employs the Grover operator instead of the Hadamard matrix to expedite the process.
We demonstrated how to use this new technology to solve the GIP with a high probability when the number of vertices in the two graphs is equal or differs by at most one unit.
Finally, we will compare our results with other state-of-the-art methods.
In recent years, there has been an increasing interest in developing efficient solutions to problems related to computational complexity theory, such as the graph isomorphism problem (GIP).
This question involves determining whether two given graphs are isomorphic; that is, whether they have the same structure without considering their labels.
The classic image recognition (GIP) solutions typically rely on random walk techniques and some heuristics.
However, these methods require exponential time in the worst case.
On the other hand, quantum algorithms provide polynomial-time solutions for many NP-complete problems, including GIP.
These algorithms utilize the principle of superposition, allowing them to explore all possible states simultaneously.
For example, the Shor algorithm solves the integer factorization problem in polynomial time, while Grover's search algorithm finds any item in a database in lower time complexity (quadratic time).

From this work, we propose a contact-based worm interaction model to evaluate the performance of different node characteristics in detecting and preventing the spread of worms in Mobile Ad Hoc Networks (MANETs).

We consider two types of nodes with different detection and prevention capabilities against worms: regular nodes, which are susceptible to worm infections but can be detected using signature detection techniques; and immune nodes, which have no vulnerabilities to worm infections but can prevent worm propagation through isolation mechanisms.
The proposed model is used to study how these two types of nodes interact when they encounter each other during network operation.

In particular, our results indicate that: 1) immune nodes play a significant role in reducing the number of infected nodes and the total contact frequency between susceptible nodes and infected nodes; 2) immune nodes should be deployed in strategic positions within MANETs; 3) immune nodes should focus not only on isolating infected nodes but also on isolating suspicious nodes; 4) immune nodes should use both signature detection and isolation mechanisms to better combat worm propagation; 5) immune nodes should adopt dynamic isolation strategies rather than static ones, as static isolation may lead to unnecessary isolation of legitimate nodes.
Extracting fresh water and energy from the atmosphere has been proposed as an alternative to traditional sources, as the supply of traditional sources is limited or harmful to the environment.

The process involves using solar energy to condense moisture from the atmosphere into liquid water, which is then collected on surfaces coated with hydrophobic materials for easy transportation by airflow.
This technology will provide clean drinking water to remote communities without the need for a large amount of land area or infrastructure investment.
It also has potential applications in agriculture, as it can provide irrigation at a low cost by using wind-powered sprayers.
Additionally, the collected water could potentially be used directly as fuel if combined with electrolyzers powered by renewable electricity.
The process requires minimal maintenance after installation and will continue to operate for many years.
Between 2011 and 2013, a pilot scale demonstration system was built near Tucson, Arizona.
The results show that under favorable conditions, the system can generate up to 1 gallon of drinking water per day.

Introduction: Recent studies have shown that the World Surface σ model (WSSM) provides a powerful framework for exploring quantum gravity through its connection with gravitational path integrals.

One particularly interesting aspect of this method is that the perturbative corrections to the WSSM action can be calculated directly through gravitational path integrals, without resorting to explicit calculations involving gravitons or graviton loops [3].
In [4], it is suggested to use WSSM to study the effective changes under renormalization group (RG).
However, since WSSM contains infinitely many degrees of freedom, there is no finite-dimensional parameter space for the RG flow.
On the contrary, the RG flow can proceed along some infinite-dimensional trajectory in all possible action spaces.

In order to better understand these trajectories, it would be very helpful to define a reasonable metric in the space of WSSM interactions, so that the distances between different interactions can be measured.
Such a metric should allow people to determine whether two given actions are closely adjacent or relatively far apart in all possible WSSM spaces.

We propose a bridging algorithm, which is an efficient direct tree-mixing n-body method that can be used to simulate fully self-consistent star clusters in the potential of galaxies with arbitrary mass distributions.

The Nullstellensatz is an important theorem in algebraic geometry, which states that if a system of polynomial equations has no solutions over a certain field, then it must have at least one solution in the algebraic closure of that field.
In this work, we demonstrate how to use the Nullstellensatz as part of a general framework to represent combinatorial optimization problems (COPs) as polynomial equation systems.
We demonstrate our approach on multiple combinatorial optimization problems (COPs), including maximum clique, minimum vertex cover, and maximum independent set.

The zero-point theorem provides a powerful tool for solving certain specific categories of computational problems that can be represented by polynomial equations.

It points out that if such a system has no solutions over a given domain K, then there exists at least one solution in the algebraic closure of K. In this paper, we propose a general method for transforming combinatorial optimization problems into systems of polynomial equations, the solvability of which can be determined using the zero-point theorem.
Our method relies on representing each feasible solution as a point in a vector space \( V \) equipped with an appropriate inner product.
Then, we represent the objective function of the problem as a linear combination of polynomials in V.

Most of the redshifts of these candidates have been found to be lower than expected; we found that this is mainly due to contamination from low-redshift interlopers that have similar optical-to-near-infrared colors.
"However, we have also identified several robust candidates that were not found in previous investigations."
This includes two objects, which have spectral confirmations of Lyman break features at z = 7.071 and z = 7.085.

We discussed the potential reasons why our sample might differ from previously published samples, including the differences between the survey areas used and the different methods of selecting spectral targets.
The gravitational lensing effect was first predicted by Einstein in 1915, but it was not confirmed by observations until 50 years later.
In this speech, I will describe a specific event—the Nova in the constellation Gemini in 1912—and how it played an important role in inspiring Einstein to develop his theory of general relativity.
This speech is based on my recently published book "The First Gravitational Lens Event" (Cambridge University Press).
The gravitational lensing effect occurs when light rays pass near a massive object, such as a galaxy or galaxy cluster.
This causes the light to bend towards each other, making distant objects appear enlarged and distorted.
In 1919, Einstein published his famous field equations, which describe gravity as the curvature of spacetime caused by matter/energy.
These equations can explain many phenomena, including the precession of Mercury's orbit around the Sun.
However, these equations still have some difficult points that are hard to solve.
For example, they do not predict that light will bend when it is near the sun.
Einstein realized that if he wanted his original field equations to explain the gravitational lensing effect, he needed to modify them.
He introduced the concept we now refer to as the cosmological constant in the new set of equations.
However, despite decades of extensive efforts, no one has been able to measure the value of this constant with sufficient accuracy to verify whether Einstein's predictions are correct.
This lecture discussed how astronomers successfully observed the phenomenon of gravitational lensing in 1979 by observing a distant quasar called Q0957+561A-B.
This also explains why the discovery of gravitational lensing earned Roger Blandford and Roman Vishniac the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1997.

We indicate that the exchange-only optimized effective potentials (OEPs) are generally not equivalent to the Kohn-Sham (KS) method, even when using exact density functionals for exchange-correlation energy.
We demonstrate this by analytically solving the optimized effective potential (OEP) for two simple model systems using Gaussian-type orbitals as basis functions.
The results obtained from these two methods show significant differences.
Specifically, we found that the KS method does not correctly evaluate the total energy of these systems.
This is because the KS equation does not have a solution corresponding to all possible densities that can be generated by the given basis set.
On the other hand, the OEP (Optimal Effective Potential) form always provides a unique solution for any given density matrix.
Our analysis also indicates how to resolve the apparent paradox that arises when attempting to apply OEP formalism using only a limited number of basis functions.

We consider the periodic oscillation of an adiabatic piston that is in contact with two ideal gases that have different temperatures and pressures, separated by a rigid wall.
We prove that if the initial state is close to equilibrium, there exists a unique global solution that converges to its limit cycle at an exponential rate as time approaches infinity.
The proof relies on a combination of techniques from nonlinear analysis (Lyapunov functions) and dynamical theory (Boltzmann equations).
In this work, we studied the dynamics of an adiabatic cylinder system, which consists of a one-dimensional ideal gas confined between two walls.
One wall is fixed, while the other moves periodically according to a certain set of rules.
This problem has been extensively studied since the pioneering work of Maxwell, Boltzmann, and Sackur-Tetrode.
Cercignani [Cerc] rigorously proved that under appropriate assumptions about piston motion, the convergence speed of the solution approaches its limit cycle rapidly in an exponential manner.
However, it seems difficult to extend his results to the case where the temperature difference on both sides of the piston always remains small.
Here, we demonstrate how to overcome this difficulty by using new ideas based on Lyapunov functions and estimates derived from control theory.
Vapor pressure, solubility in water, and oil-water interfacial tension are important parameters for understanding the behavior of crude oil during production or when transported through pipelines.
In this study, we used alcohol monolayers in an aqueous phase as a model system to investigate these properties, simulating the hydrocarbon chains present in crude oil.
The results show that the vapor pressure of alcohol compounds increases with chain length up to C8, but then decreases for chain lengths above C10.
This can be explained by considering the competition between two opposing effects: on one hand, the increased chain length leads to a higher molecular volume, which favors evaporation.
On the other hand, longer chains can also lead to an increase in van der Waals forces in the liquid phase, resulting in a lower vapor pressure.
We found that the solubility of alcohols shows a similar trend to the observed vapor pressure.
However, when compared to the corresponding differences in vapor pressure, the differences in solubility between different chain lengths become smaller.
Finally, our measurement results show that the interfacial tension between the alcohol layer and the underlying water decreases monotonically with increasing chain length.
We present new near-infrared (NIR) spectral and photometric measurements of the Herbig Be star HD 98800, which is surrounded by an optically thick dust disk with a radius of about 200 AU.
The NIR spectrum shows strong emission lines from H I, He II, C III, O IV-VI, Si IV, S VI, Fe II, Mg II, Al II-III, Na I, Ca II, and K I, as well as absorption features caused by stellar winds.
We found that the observed spectral line profiles are consistent with the predictions from magnetohydrodynamic models of accretion disks around young stars.
Specifically, we detected blue-shifted absorption associated with gas streams falling into the central star along the magnetic field lines.
These results indicate that HD 98800 has been experiencing active material accumulation over the past few million years.
Keywords: gradually increasing, Herbig B star

We analyzed the gravitational lensing data of the galaxy cluster Abell 1689, which is located at redshift z = 0.183. This galaxy cluster has been observed by the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) in three bands (F450W, F625W, F775W).
We used these observational data to reconstruct the intrinsic triaxial shape of this large-scale star cluster using two different methods.

First, we apply the method developed by Sereno and Umetsu (2006), in which the projection quality distribution on the sky is modeled as a superposition of elliptical NFW halos with different axis ratios.
Secondly, we adopted the technique proposed by Corless et al. (2009), in which the three-dimensional density distribution is described by a generalized Navarro-Frenk-White model.
These two models simultaneously fit the HST shear measurement data obtained within a circular aperture centered on the brightest galaxy.
The best fit parameters inferred from the two methods are very consistent with each other.

We demonstrated the results of the gradual formation of primitive gas giant planets through the accretion of solid bodies in protoplanetary disks of varying quality and composition, using three-dimensional hydrodynamic simulations coupled with N-body integrators.
We found that the growth rate is closely related to the mass of the disk; disks with greater mass lead to faster timescales for planet formation.

The final planet mass mainly depends on the initial surface density distribution of the disk at large radii (>100 AU), which determines how much material can be transported inward before it dissipates.
In addition, we indicate that the composition of the disk has only a minor influence on the final characteristics of the planet.

Our model can reproduce the trends observed in the metallicity of host stars and the occurrence rate of giant planets, as well as the distribution of orbital periods and eccentricities of known exoplanets.
This indicates that our model captures the important physical processes involved in the formation of gas giants.
Keywords: planetary system; giant planet
We studied the process of muon decay into two neutrinos, an electron-positron pair, and a photon using the Feynman diagram method.

We found that the emitted neutrinos have three types: Type I is emitted when the energy of the emitted photons is less than half the rest mass of the gluon; Type II is emitted when the energy is greater than or equal to half the rest mass of the gluon but less than twice that; Type III is emitted when the energy of particles with spin 1/2 is less than twice their respective standard mass.
The probability distribution functions for these three types are shown for different values of the parameter \( x = \frac{Eγ}{2 mμ} \).
The results obtained here are consistent with the previously given results.
Keywords: muon decay, neutrino emission, Feynman diagram technique, probability distribution function, standard model.

We used three-dimensional fluid dynamics simulations to study the gravitational instability (GI) between two differentially rotating self-gravitating disks, including cases with and without magnetic fields.
We found that in both cases, baryon generation (GI) can occur at large radii, but it is suppressed in the strong magnetic field near the central star.
The mass of the disk required to trigger gravitational instability decreases with increasing radius, as the Toomre Q parameter decreases due to the weakening of stellar gravity.
In the absence of a magnetic field, we also study how the initial density distribution affects the growth rate of gravitational instability.
Our results indicate that the growth time scale depends on the radial distribution of surface density.
In addition, we also studied whether geographic information (GI) would lead to fragmentation.
Fragmentation occurs only when there is a steep surface density gradient at the beginning on the disk.
Finally, we discussed the possible implications of our findings on planet formation.

Gravitational instability (GI) can lead to the formation of spiral arms in gravitationally bound systems, such as parabolic galaxies, which may play an important role in various astrophysical phenomena, including planet formation.

However, it is currently unclear whether gravitational instability (GI) plays a role in the protoplanetary disks around young stars, as these disks can be magnetized and their rotational characteristics are very complex.
Here, we conduct three-dimensional fluid dynamics simulations to investigate this issue.

The radial distribution of the internal magnetosphere (IM) plasma pressure was studied by analyzing magnetic field and particle measurements taken from two low-altitude satellites in the equatorial plane during a strong geomagnetic storm that occurred between March 1 and March 5, 1982.
The results show that there are significant differences in the IM plasma pressure profiles obtained by different satellites.
Especially, the pressure profile derived from GEOS-1 observations shows a sharp peak near L=3, while the peak inferred from ATS-6 and GEOS-2 data presents a broader peak near L=4.
These differences may be due to the different orbits of these satellites, which sampled different spatial areas.
The research also found that when the pressure profiles inferred from three satellites are moved outward along the L-shell coordinate system, the results are very consistent with each other.
This indicates that the observed differences in pressure distribution can mainly be attributed to spatial variations in pressure, rather than temporal variations.

We prove that this quantity can be expressed as a solution to a fixed-point equation that involves the Laplace transform of the offspring distribution.

We have obtained specific bounds on the exponential growth rate when all descendants are distributed according to a Poisson or geometric distribution.
Finally, we provide some examples to illustrate our main results.
Keywords: branching process; typed branching diffusion; exponential growth rate; fixed-point equation.

The evolution of a star is driven by the nuclear fusion reactions in its core, and the energy produced by these reactions powers the star's luminosity.
The rate at which these reactions occur depends on the amount of fuel available for combustion (i.e., helium).
In its red giant phase, the core contracts and becomes denser and hotter, increasing the pressure within the core until the temperature reaches about one hundred million degrees Celsius.
At this moment, helium begins to burn rapidly, releasing a large amount of energy to the surrounding plasma.
This causes the outer layers of the star to expand outward due to the increased pressure generated within the core.
Ultimately, the expanded outer layer becomes so thin that it can no longer resist gravity; consequently, the star collapses inward again, forming a white dwarf or a neutron star.

In addition to the nuclear fusion reactions that occur in their cores, some massive stars also undergo explosive nuclear fusion reactions known as supernovae, which eject most of the star's mass into space.
These explosions release a large amount of energy and light, making them visible from a distance in the night sky.
